title: The Antichrist
author: Nietzsche, Friedrich
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The anti-Semitism, misogyny, and eugenicist barbarism in The Antichrist strike me much more now as a 50-year-old than they did when I first read this The anti-Semitism, misogyny, and eugenicist barbarism in The Antichrist strike me much more now as a 50-year-old than they did when I first read this in graduate school over 20 years ago. Nevertheless, Nietzsche presents a trenchant critique of belief as a a legitimate way of knowing, of the denial of the goods of this world in favor of imagined immortality in another world, and of the ecclesiastical crusade against science and truth. Yet the Christianity that Nietzsche assails is often a straw man (or, at least, he fails to account for the multivariant expressions of Christianity that would side with him against the corrupt and dishonest religion that he is here attacking), and his arguments are frequently matters more of aesthetics than of logic or philosophy. The Antichrist is a great literary response to certain forms of degenerate and intellectually dishonest Christianity, and Nietzsche’s prose is often delightfully witty and brilliant, but this is not a work of rigorous philosophy and is extremely problematic due especially to its misogyny, anti-Semitism, and fascistic tendencies....more

title: Swann's Way        (Remembrance of Things Past, #1)
author: Proust, Marcel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This first volume of Remembrance of Things Past was not sufficiently compelling to motivate me to read any further volumes of Proust’s magnum opus. PrThis first volume of Remembrance of Things Past was not sufficiently compelling to motivate me to read any further volumes of Proust’s magnum opus. Proust’s prose is often unquestionably beautiful and poetic, but it is also labyrinthine in the worst ways: paragraphs that run for pages describing nothing more interesting than a stroll through the countryside; long sentences with multiple relative clauses, appositive phrases, subordinate clauses, and parenthetical asides such that the very convoluted structure of the the sentence renders the sentence almost unintelligible without re-reading it. And what do we get for the Herculean effort of wading through a morass of viscous language? We get the narrator’s psychological self-analysis of his early childhood and Swann’s tiresome obsession with Odette—hundreds of pages of Swann’s stalkerish ponderings and wonderings about where Odette is and what she is doing and thinking and whether he is present in her thoughts and what he might be able to do to meet with her without her becoming annoyed with him. It’s all so very trivial while being a chore to read. There is no plot here, no story—just fragments and descriptions of the lives of the narrator, his family, and Swann. This is not a novel so much as an exquisitely detailed (though partially fictionalized) journal. It is not an enjoyable read except for rare passages of brilliance, and it is due to these rare passages that I have rated this volume three stars instead of two.This may be one of the masterpieces of world literature, and it indeed often showcases beautiful and stunning writing, but it is not for me....more

title: Truly Madly Guilty
author: Moriarty, Liane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There are very few writers whose new books I feel I must read as soon as they are published. Liane Moriarty is one of those writers.While I would rateThere are very few writers whose new books I feel I must read as soon as they are published. Liane Moriarty is one of those writers.While I would rate her last novel, Big Little Lies as ever so slightly better than her latest, Truly Madly Guilty, Truly Madly Guilty does not disappoint. As usual, Moriarty is a master of building up tension and teasing out an explosive mystery with one bombshell revelation after another. In Truly Madly Guilty, we get four major revelations (view spoiler)[the revelation of Ruby's near-drowning after her fall into the fountain, the revelation that it was Harry who had alerted Erika to Ruby's falling into the pool, the revelation that Harry had been rushing down the stairs to Vid and Tiffany's to rescue Ruby when he fell to his death, and the revelation that Holly had pushed her sister into the fountain (hide spoiler)], and all of them left me breathless and even, in the last two instances, near tears.Moriarty also delivers fascinating characters, all with their own peculiar flaws and strengths. Even if we didn't have the central mystery of the novel, we would still be highly entertained by watching these characters (primarily the women in this novel--Erika, Clementine, and Tiffany--but the men--Oliver, Sam, and Vid--also have strong roles to play) interact with each other and their families. This is a great cast of well-drawn, realistic, engaging characters.If you like plot-heavy novels, Truly Madly Guilty is for you. If you like character-driven novels, Truly Madly Guilty is for you. If you like fast-paced, highly entertaining literature, Truly Madly Guilty is for you. So, to summarize, if you're a human being, Truly Madly Guilty is for you!...more

title: Tender is the Flesh
author: Bazterrica, Agustina
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a novella that, like many other great works of literature, tells not only a fascinating—though extraordinarily disturbing—tale but also raisesThis is a novella that, like many other great works of literature, tells not only a fascinating—though extraordinarily disturbing—tale but also raises some very important philosophical and ethical questions. What are our ethical obligations to animals? Is eating meat and conducting laboratory tests on animals moral? How would the major meta-ethical schools (Kantian deontology, utilitarianism, Aristotelian virtue theory) evaluate the actions of the society depicted in this novella, and what light can these evaluations shed on our overall assessment of each of these schools of thought?This is a story that will definitely stick with most readers because it pulls no punches in showing the sheer brutality and callousness of the meat industry and depicts humanity at its most depraved. As a vegan, I was particularly struck by this extended parable. I don’t know if the author is vegan, but her story is one of the best arguments for veganism that I have ever encountered in literature....more

review: This murder mystery has, overall, very good s, but it really wasn’t for me. The characters were thinly drawn, and they were almost all either unThis murder mystery has, overall, very good s, but it really wasn’t for me. The characters were thinly drawn, and they were almost all either unpleasant or bland; the story did not make me care for any of them. As for the mystery itself, it’s extremely convoluted, which is sometimes good but here, coupled with the uninspiring characters, left me generally uninterested in the identity of the killer. Finally, this book just tried too hard: you could feel the author working at being clever and funny—but not really succeeding. Still, it was interesting enough that I finished it, so there is that, but I can’t recommend it....more

review: As a huge tennis fan, I was pretty sure that I would like this novel. But I was not prepared for how much I loved it. This is absolutely terrific sporAs a huge tennis fan, I was pretty sure that I would like this novel. But I was not prepared for how much I loved it. This is absolutely terrific sports fiction. I was on the edge of my seat with anticipation throughout; for all of the match scenes, I felt like I was physically present at a grand slam match, my heart in my throat as Carrie Soto battled her opponents. But this was more than a story about tennis. The characters, relationships, and rivalries were perfectly crafted. I really loved and cared about these characters and their journeys. This book was an utter delight in every respect....more

review: 3.5 starsThis is a novel of ideas and ideals, brilliant and laudable, and l love the novel’s anti-colonialist agenda. But the story itself falters; th3.5 starsThis is a novel of ideas and ideals, brilliant and laudable, and l love the novel’s anti-colonialist agenda. But the story itself falters; the plot simmers but never comes to a boil, and the resolution—though realistic—is disappointing and left me feeling hollow. I wanted more story and less lecturing, more character development and fewer linguistic tangents, more magic and less convoluted explanations of how the magic worked. This novel has great potential, but it does not quite strike the right (satisfying, enjoyable) narrative chord. Still, this novel is well written and has a great message, but that wasn’t quite enough to make me love it....more

title: The Jungle
author: Sinclair, Upton
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: No novel better highlights the harrowing, horrifying plight of the working class in the United States in the early 1900s than does The Jungle. FocusinNo novel better highlights the harrowing, horrifying plight of the working class in the United States in the early 1900s than does The Jungle. Focusing on a family of immigrants from Lithuania, The Jungle shows in graphic, sickening detail how capitalism destroyed the health, the spirit, and the lives of millions.While the novel is a brilliant extended argument for socialism, it is also the heartbreaking and fascinating tale of Jurgis Rudkus and his family. The Jungle is the tragedy of both Jurgis and his family and of the United States. I was appalled and horrified by this novel and reminded of the importance of the socialist cause. While The Jungle is recognized as an important piece of literary journalism, I think it is vastly underrated. This novel is a must read for anyone who cares about the plight of the poor and the working class, whose struggle continues still....more

title: Jesus Before the Gospels: How the Earliest Christians Remembered, Changed, and Invented Their Stories of the Savior
author: Ehrman, Bart D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have read three of Bart Ehrman‘s other books, and this book, in my opinion, is the best of those that I have read. Ehrman presents some fascinating I have read three of Bart Ehrman‘s other books, and this book, in my opinion, is the best of those that I have read. Ehrman presents some fascinating research on memory—how it works individually, collectively, and sociologically—and on oral transmission in non-literate and largely non-literate cultures. He then takes what we have learned from psychologists, sociologists, and cultural anthropologists and applies it to the development of the early Christian traditions of the life and teachings of Jesus. This is an approach that I never encountered in my graduate school theological studies and have not seen much work on in mainstream New Testament scholarship. I was impressed with the originality, relevance, and importance of this approach....more

title: Rock Paper Scissors
author: Feeney, Alice*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As readers, we often make assumptions that are not illogical and that do make narrative sense. A good author knows that readers will make these types As readers, we often make assumptions that are not illogical and that do make narrative sense. A good author knows that readers will make these types of assumptions and then surprises us with a different narrative development (also not illogical and also that makes narrative sense) that we could possibly have seen coming but simply overlooked. This is not necessarily a twist but rather is the author cleverly taking account of the readers’ likely presumptions about the narrative development.Like most readers of this novel, I made an assumption. When my assumption turned out to be radically wrong, I was shocked—to the point that I literally yelled out loud. And it was a fun and fabulous shock that re-shaped my entire perspective on this story.This is the fourth Alice Feeney novel that I have read, and she continually proves herself to be a master thriller writer. I will read anything and everything that she publishes, and I cannot wait to read her latest novel, which comes out later this month.Bravo, Ms. Feeney! Bravo!...more

title: Search
author: Huneven, Michelle*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Search is the most delightful, engaging novel that I have read this year (2022). I laughed out loud too many times to count and even shed a few tears.Search is the most delightful, engaging novel that I have read this year (2022). I laughed out loud too many times to count and even shed a few tears. This novel is why I read books. There are not enough superlatives to describe how much I loved it, so all I can say to my fellow readers--but especially to anyone in the ministry or to anyone who has attended a small church or attended seminary--is, "Read this book as soon as you can!"On the face of it, the story of a small church's search committee's endeavor to find a new minister might not sound terribly interesting, but in the expert hands of Michelle Huneven, who shows herself to be a master storyteller, this tale is utterly captivating. The narrator, Dana, is so well drawn and such a sympathetic character that I found myself completely identifying with her--suffering all her frustrations and angst and reveling in her joys and friendships, and I disliked and rooted against her nemesis, Jennie, while still finding a soft spot in my heart even for Jennie. Dana, Jennie, and all of the other members of the search committee as well as the church's current, retiring minister and all of the minster candidates are fully incarnated in the text. Huneven's ability to portray fully realized characters is an exceedingly rare and wonderful talent. All of these characters moved from the page and into my head as real, living people, and I wanted to chat with them and argue with them about the ministerial selection process and about theology and philosophy and to have cocktails with them and dine with them. Even when I put this book down (for work, sleep, etc.), I could not stop thinking about the characters and wondering how the selection process would turn out, and when I picked the book back up, I was immediately fully re-engaged with the story and back in my happy place.I cannot express how much I loved this book. It reminded me not only of my days in seminary and the wonderful, friendly, and sometimes even heated arguments that I had with my fellow seminarians but also of my time growing up in a small church and all of the gossip and turmoil and love and good fellowship and good food that are an inescapable part of any congregation.I loved Michelle Huneven's earlier novel, Blame, and Search has given me such great enjoyment and intellectual pleasure than I cannot wait to see she does next.Bravo, Ms. Huneven! Bravo!...more

title: Sandy Hook: An American Tragedy and the Battle for Truth
author: Williamson, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In the first few chapters of this book, I found myself weeping on several occasions, and that happened again several times throughout as Elizabeth WilIn the first few chapters of this book, I found myself weeping on several occasions, and that happened again several times throughout as Elizabeth Williamson recounts the terrible tragedy of the mass murder of children. As the book went along, I found myself more and more outraged by those who claim that the mass murder at Sandy Hook was a false flag operation and that the families and children involved were actors and frauds who had staged the Sandy Hook shooting in an effort to pass gun control legislation. At the end of the book, I was mainly just sad: sad for the victims and victims' families, sad that so many Americans would believe the nonsense promulgated by those who deny the reality of Sandy Hook, sad that these types of tragedies continue to occur, and sad that this type of misinformation and conspiracy theory nonsense is still all too prevalent in our society.Sandy Hook is a monumentally great work of non-fiction and, of course, calls to mind Dave Cullen's seminal book, Columbine, which is also a deep dive into a school shooting. In Sandy Hook, Elizabeth Williamson shows herself to be a wonderful researcher, a great interviewer, and brilliant writer; she pulls together reams of information to spin out a tale of horror, tragedy, outrage, and, at last, a measure of hope when, in the end, many of the Sandy Hook deniers finally have to face the consequences of their vile behavior when they lose again and again in civil court cases....more

title: It
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: miscellaneous reflections:Richie Tozier is quite possibly the most annoying character in all of literature.The human bullies in this story, Beverly‘s miscellaneous reflections:Richie Tozier is quite possibly the most annoying character in all of literature.The human bullies in this story, Beverly‘s husband Tom and Henry and his friends, are more terrifying than It.The adolescent sex scene near the end is completely ridiculous and really serves no good narrative purpose. Yes, the novel tries to give it a purpose, but it’s not a very convincing one.The way that It is first defeated in 1958 and later killed in 1985 is through the sheer belief and desire of the members of the Losers Club. It is pure magic. It’s not the best explanation, but it’s not terrible either.This novel is extremely bloated. It feels as if there were no editors to tell Stephen King he needed to make some major cuts. My version of this book comes in at 1153 pages, and it would have still been a great story with 300 fewer pages or maybe even 400 or 500 fewer pages.As in most Stephen King novels, what makes this novel really good is the characters. Even though Richie is very annoying, most readers, I think, become invested in all of the main characters and also despise the villains. Because we readers care so much about the protagonists and hate the antagonists, we find ourselves very much enjoying this macabre tale.It’s interesting that in this novel, Stephen King hints that the members of the Losers Club are ultimately helped by the Other (also referred to as Another), and the Other is fairly clearly God. Thus, in the final analysis, this novel is very dualistic: we have an ultimate source of primitive evil, It, that is finally overcome by a power that transcends this universe and It, and that power is God.While I have outlined many shortcomings in the novel, it is, nonetheless, very entertaining. And, as is usually the case, the book is much better than either of the movie versions....more

title: The Pillars of the Earth
author: Follett, Ken*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What an enthralling, endlessly entertaining, utterly magnificent, magisterial book this is! As I was reading this novel, I found myself exclaiming aloWhat an enthralling, endlessly entertaining, utterly magnificent, magisterial book this is! As I was reading this novel, I found myself exclaiming aloud on many occasions, “This book is sooooooo good!”Waleran Bigod, William Hamleigh, Alfred Builder: such perfect villains. They are not weak, paper villains. They are powerful, executing brilliantly evil schemes—often with nonchalant brutality. We readers truly fear them—but more so, we loathe them. And, oh, how we rejoice and luxuriate in their downfalls.Tom Builder, Ellen, Prior Philip, Aliena, Jack: our heroes are as good and virtuous as our villains are wicked. Though all of them have their flaws, they are ultimately good, kind, and decent. We love their virtue, their intelligence, and their courage and resolution in the face of the murder of loved ones, of debilitating poverty, of betrayal, and of relentlessly hateful enemies.While my copy of this novel was almost 1,000 pages long, reading this novel never felt like a slog. The pacing and subplots kept me fully engaged from the first page to the last. And because I fell so in love with our heroes, I was constantly worrying about them, lamenting their setbacks, and rejoicing in their triumphs. I could not turn the pages quickly enough.Ken Follett is a genius. I love The Pillars of the Earth. It is easily among the best novels that I have ever read. I picked up this novel because it is on numerous lists of the top 100 novels of the 20th century. I would go further: The Pillars of the Earth is one of the top 10 novels of the 20th century....more

review: If you think the airline disaster sub-genre is clichéd and has nothing new to offer, think again. Falling presents a unique premise that serves up heaIf you think the airline disaster sub-genre is clichéd and has nothing new to offer, think again. Falling presents a unique premise that serves up heaping helpings of suspense and action as well as a lot of genuine heart and emotion—I was shocked that this novel so endeared me to the main characters and literally brought me to tears on several occasions. This novel is also surprisingly socially and geopolitically astute and nuanced. The author, T.J. Newman, is not afraid to honestly show the humanity and even the goodness that her antagonists possess. She is gifted both at storytelling and in depicting realistic characters. She is definitely a writer to watch, and this novel will undoubtedly show up on a ton of lists of the best novels of 2021.Falling is the perfect summer vacation thriller—but maybe don’t read it while on the flight to your vacation spot. Wait until you are safely off the plane!...more

review: After reading and loving Razorblade Tears last month, I was compelled to read Mr. Cosby’s earlier novel, Blacktop Wasteland. This is crime fiction at its finest. And it’s more than just crime fiction: it’s a great character study with an unforgettable protagonist in Beauregard (Bug) Montage and great supporting cast of family, friends, frenemies, and flat-out nasty villains. Mr. Cosby is now on my list of writers whose new books must be read as soon as they are published. If you want some guaranteed good reads, get Blacktop Wasteland and Razorblade Tears into your hands as soon as possible....more

review: Racism, homophobia, and transphobia collide in this novel that begins as a murder mystery and progresses as a revenge thriller. This novel is John WicRacism, homophobia, and transphobia collide in this novel that begins as a murder mystery and progresses as a revenge thriller. This novel is John Wick and Pulp Fiction infused with astute social commentary on the very real issues that black Americans, gay Americans, and trans Americans face on a daily basis. It is also a story of family, friendship, and love. Razorblade Tears is easily the best novel that I have read so far in 2021 and one of the best crime novels I have ever read. It is brutal and dark. It is full of fear and hate yet also love and hope. The action never slows, and it is the incarnation of entertainment. if you want to see just how good contemporary fiction can be, read this novel. There is no way that you will be disappointed....more

review: The renowned astronomer, Johannes Kepler, in the prime of his life, had to defend his mother, Katharina Kepler, from charges of witchcraft. This novelThe renowned astronomer, Johannes Kepler, in the prime of his life, had to defend his mother, Katharina Kepler, from charges of witchcraft. This novel is a fictionalized account of Katharina’s life in the small German village where she was accused and of her trial. Rivka Galchen brings Katharina, her famous son, and her family, friends, and accusers to fully realized, earthy life. Katharina is portrayed as a sharp, witty, no-nonsense woman who loves her family and friends and even her cow but who brooks no tolerance for fools. The novel is at turns hilarious and harrowing and is an engrossing read....more

review: I saw the film once years ago but had no substantial recollection of the plot apart from broad generalities, so I came into the novel almost with a blI saw the film once years ago but had no substantial recollection of the plot apart from broad generalities, so I came into the novel almost with a blank slate. The novel wrestles with the problems of doubt and belief, with the problem of evil, and, though pragmatically rather than philosophically, with the question of consciousness and how the brain and the mind are related. Blatty writes sympathetically about both believers and nonbelievers, and he presents the question of demonic possession with great skepticism while also leaving the door for its possibility open enough to create a terrifying narrative. This is certainly a masterpiece of horror....more

It’s hilarious because of the co-authors’ razor-sharp wit and brilliant sarcasm and disheartening because it highlights the ubiquitous racism that black women face on a daily (yes, daily!) basis, and it accomplishes this by relating the day-to-day experiences of a black woman living in a moderate-sized midwestern city (Omaha, Nebraska). I laughed out loud and gasped in horror so many times that my wife was continually asking me what was going on in this book, and the answer was always: just the insane racism that a black woman has to deal with from clueless, bigoted white folks....more

review: This is an intricately crafted novel with so many narrative strands woven together beautifully and with unique, wonderful, unforgettable characters: DThis is an intricately crafted novel with so many narrative strands woven together beautifully and with unique, wonderful, unforgettable characters: Dr. Larch, Homer Wells, Melony, Wally, Candy, and Mister Rose. The Cider House Rules is the equal of The World According to Garp and nearly as good as John Irving’s inimitable masterpiece A Prayer for Owen Meany. I think John Irving may be the greatest novelist of the past hundred years. He writes with a humane, kind spirit and a great understanding of the human condition, and he spins stories within stories within stories that all connect together into a flawless whole. His narrative voice touches the soul and flows with a comfortable and comforting familiarity. Reading his effortless, graceful prose, you know that you are on a wonderful, endlessly entertaining and educational journey....more

review: The title seemed a bit too precious to me initially, but I gave it a shot anyway. The scene where a cockroach is slowly crawling into Patricia’s (the The title seemed a bit too precious to me initially, but I gave it a shot anyway. The scene where a cockroach is slowly crawling into Patricia’s (the protagonist’s) ear while she is hiding from the vampire and then she smushes her ear too crush the cockroach—yeah, that’s not precious at all. I love this book. It’s gory and scary. I literally cringed and winced out loud numerous times, making my wife look quizzically at the sounds I was uttering. Very few novels really scare me. This one had me holding my breath with fearful anticipation as I turned the pages.I love a good hateful villain, and this novel delivers there. I wanted to jump into the pages and mix it up with James myself. This guy! Ugh! I hate him so much!And it’s not just an entertaining read: the novel kicks the patriarchy right in the junk! review: My wife is a therapist, so I was intrigued when I saw this book by a therapist about her career as a therapist and her own experiences going to therapMy wife is a therapist, so I was intrigued when I saw this book by a therapist about her career as a therapist and her own experiences going to therapy. I thought I already knew a lot about therapy from what I know of my wife’s career, but I really learned so much by reading this book. I laughed out loud and sobbed heartfelt tears too many times to count while reading this marvelous book, and I found myself looking at my own life in new and meaningful ways. In a way, reading this book felt like I was going to therapy myself, and I found this therapy helped me understand myself and my relationships better. It was truly helpful therapy.I have never been one to read self-help books, and I would not consider this a self-help book, yet, paradoxically, this book, even though I definitely do not think of it as a self-help book, helped me. review: Gifty, the daughter of Ghanaian immigrants, is a neuroscience graduate student at Stanford wrestling with her past and trying to find herself in the pGifty, the daughter of Ghanaian immigrants, is a neuroscience graduate student at Stanford wrestling with her past and trying to find herself in the present. She grew up in an Assemblies of God church in Alabama, and though she has left her Pentecostal faith behind, she is still on a spiritual journey as she tries to cope with the consequences of her brother’s opioid addiction, her mother’s clinical depression, her father’s absence, and what place, if any, God has in her life as a scientist and as a woman scarred by an indifferent universe.Yaa Gyasi tells Gifty’s story eloquently and with a deep understanding of how early religious experience continues to shape and mold personality even if that religion is left behind. title: The Room Where It Happened: A White House Memoir
author: Bolton, John R.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** This is not a salacious, gossip-laden memoir about the Trump Administration. It is a straightforward, highly detailed, candid recoun**spoiler alert** This is not a salacious, gossip-laden memoir about the Trump Administration. It is a straightforward, highly detailed, candid recounting of John Bolton‘s time as President Trump’s national security advisor. This book is not a “hit piece” against Donald Trump or Republicans. In fact, Bolton spends as much, if not more, time critiquing the policies and diplomacy of the Obama Administration than he does critiquing Trump. The vast majority of the book covers the day-to-day work of Bolton as national security advisor. For the first 100 pages or so, I found he book a bit tedious as Bolton describes in detail the intricacies of negotiations with sundry foreign diplomats, officials, and heads of state as well as the internal policy-making apparatus of the Trump Administration. As the book went on, however, I came to find it very informative and even engaging. More than anything else, I came away from this book with a newfound respect for Bolton—someone with whom I, as a pacifist and liberal, have found myself disagreeing with strongly in the past on foreign policy—and his realpolitik approach to foreign affairs. This memoir shows Bolton to be a dedicated public servant and an American patriot who truly has the best interests of his country at heart.For those who are looking for a book that will glaringly indict Trump as a corrupt president, there is little in this book that has not been published in other tell-all books of the last few years. What separates this book from other books on the Trump presidency is that it is written by a staunch conservative Republican who never waivers in his commitment to his conservative principles.Bolton’s prose is blunt and pointed, and he never downplays his opinions, especially in regards to his strong disagreements with the Obama Administration‘s policies and his frustrations with Trump’s fickleness and lack of focus.Bolton never offers an opinion on whether Trump should have been removed from office. He indicates that he is very disturbed by what he observed during his time working in the Trump Administration, with his view most succinctly summarized in this quote: “This showed the asymmetry of Trump’s view of foreign affairs. He couldn’t tell the difference between his personal interests and the country’s interests” (page 348). Having now read this book, I am impressed with John Bolton as a man of great integrity, and, surprisingly, I find myself in many ways much more sympathetic to Bolton’s views and approaches to foreign policy.One final note on Bolton’s style: he has a very dry sense of humor, which made me laugh out loud on numerous occasions. As disturbing as much of this book is, it is also quite funny in many places....more

review: This is only my second John Irving novel (the first being A Prayer for Owen Meany), but on the strength of just these two novels, I would have to say This is only my second John Irving novel (the first being A Prayer for Owen Meany), but on the strength of just these two novels, I would have to say that John Irving is one of the greatest American writers of the last half century—maybe even the greatest. He is a consummate storyteller with better prose than Nabakov. His writing is human, humane, and hilarious with perfectly realized characters and bizarre yet somehow all too believable story lines. He makes you love his characters, and his narrative voice is so gentle and loving—as soothing as a hot cappuccino on a cool, rainy weekend morning. I certainly will be reading more of his novels.As for this novel: what an epic tragicomedy! Funny, sweet, sad, audacious, caring, and even, at times, harrowing and violent. I love Garp and all his family and friends! What a wonderful adventure!...more

title: The Experience of God: Being, Consciousness, Bliss
author: Hart, David Bentley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The debates between atheists (particularly the New Atheists) and theists of the last two decades have, to a degree, been debates that failed to accounThe debates between atheists (particularly the New Atheists) and theists of the last two decades have, to a degree, been debates that failed to account for the classical theistic understanding of God.This book is not principally an effort to refute those atheist (and rehashed New Atheist) arguments but an effort to properly and robustly define and explicate the classical theistic concept of God. In this effort, David Bentley Hart succeeds brilliantly. The chapters on being (ontology) and consciousness are especially strong.I don’t think there are any easy answers in the debate about the existence of God, nor do I find David Bentley Hart’s arguments entirely convincing; however, they are nonetheless very persuasive. For anyone who wants a philosophically and theologically sophisticated examination of the question of God, this is a fantastic book....more

title: American Psycho
author: Ellis, Bret Easton
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Near the end of this novel, the eponymous psycho who narrates the story tells us, “There has been no reason for me to tell you any of this. This confeNear the end of this novel, the eponymous psycho who narrates the story tells us, “There has been no reason for me to tell you any of this. This confession has meant nothing . . . .” (italics in original). I really can’t disagree with him here.This novel seems to be trying to skewer the Wall Street culture of the mid- to late-1980s—to mock the greed, the materialism, the selfishness that so many identify with that era. But it doesn’t really succeed. Instead of a satirical look at the era, the novel sinks into the depths of absurdism. This might be forgivable if there were more redeeming literary value. And there is some: the novel is, at times, very funny, but for the most part, this novel has little to offer the reader other than vapid dialogue among paper-thin characters. There is really no plot; we just watch our protagonist, Patrick Bateman, dialoguing with himself about fashion (to a painfully boring degree) and the latest music and video technology and conversing with others in an endless string of bars and restaurants and conversing mostly about bars and restaurants.And, finally, what turns this novel from a run-of-the-mill, forgettable but passable read to a work of filth is the horrific pornography. This novel revels in murder, in inhuman violence, and in torture of the most gruesomely disgusting kind. I don’t think I have ever called a novel a work of filth before, but here I definitely think it is appropriate. The murder and torture scenes are extravagantly horrific and serve no purpose other than to shock the reader.And yet for all that, I am still rating this novel as two stars instead of one star. It is still well written with a fascinating look into the mind of a psychopath, and Brett Easton Ellis does have an interesting point to make, but he sabotages himself and the entire novel with the torture pornography.Possibly the best writing in the entire novel were the three chapters that were extended s of Genesis, Whitney Houston, and Huey Lewis and the News. Possibly the most hysterical thing in this novel – aside from Patrick Bateman’s constant reference to needing to return videotapes as an excuse for anything and everything – is Bateman’s assertion that Huey Lewis and the News is the greatest rock band of the 1980s; apart from the vile pornography, it is in this assertion that we truly see the nadir of Bateman’s insanity.In the end, I come back to the quote near the novel’s end that perfectly summarizes how I feel about it: “There has been no reason for me to tell you any of this. This confession has meant nothing . . . .” (italics in original)....more

review: That All Shall Be Saved is David Bentley Hart at his rhetorical best: the prose is caustic and engaging; the logic, rigorous; the scriptural hermeneutThat All Shall Be Saved is David Bentley Hart at his rhetorical best: the prose is caustic and engaging; the logic, rigorous; the scriptural hermeneutics and exegesis, thoughtful and well reasoned. review: 3.5 stars rounded up to 4 starsThere are too many fortuitous coincidences.The dialogue (especially the Count's long speeches) is often sentimental, ve3.5 stars rounded up to 4 starsThere are too many fortuitous coincidences.The dialogue (especially the Count's long speeches) is often sentimental, verging on mawkish.The incredible (and I mean incredible in the sense of impossible to believe) wealth of the Count transforms him from a mere man into a god.After Edmond's early life and imprisonment (which takes up less than the first fifth of the novel), he encounters practically no obstacles whatsoever in his pursuit of vengeance; everything comes far too easily.And, yes, it is icky that the Count appears to intend to take Haydee as his bride as the novel comes to an end--Haydee, who had been like a daughter to him and whom he had known since she was a little girl of five years of age. It is definitely borderline incestuous even though there is no blood relationship.And yet I reveled in the adventure, in the fabulous wealth of the Count, in the near omnipotence that that wealth purchased, and in the turns of fortune that the Count brought about in the lives of his enemies. Dumas, departing from his tendency to portray the count as almost divine, deserves credit for making the Count all too human and showing him so overcome by his desire for vengeance that his actions toward Villefort and his family are decidedly immoral. Yes, Villefort is a key figure in Edmond's imprisonment, but two decades later, he seems to have become a fairly good man and was definitely a loving father to Valentine. The Count's inaction leads to the deaths of too many innocent people in Villefort's family, and that is unforgivable on the part of the Count, and the novel recognizes this as does the Count himself. It is nice to see such a large chink in the Count's armor in a novel in which he otherwise can do no wrong.While this is a very long novel, it is fun and enjoyable from beginning to end despite being somewhat melodramatic. I was immensely entertained....more

review: East of Eden further establishes John Steinbeck as, in my estimation, one of the greatest--if not the greatest--American novelists of the first half oEast of Eden further establishes John Steinbeck as, in my estimation, one of the greatest--if not the greatest--American novelists of the first half of the 20th century. While the narrative of this novel is rather loosely structured, meandering between the Hamiltons and the Trasks, the characters--particularly Samuel Hamilton, Adam Trask, Cathy/Kate Trask, Caleb Trask, Lee, and Abra--spring to brilliant, ebullient life on the page. As a reader, I cared more about just getting to know these characters and following their development than I did about the plot. That's not to say that the plot is lacking because it isn't; rather, the characters drive the plot and so supersede it. Steinbeck's descriptive powers of the Salinas Valley are a sensory marvel. I could see, feel, smell, and hear the farms and landscapes of the valley right along with the characters.The allegory of Adam Trask and his two sons, Caleb and Aron, to the biblical story of Adam, Cain, and Abel is not subtle at all, but it is still cleverly developed. In fact, East of Eden is less an allegory than an extended retelling of the story of Cain and Abel. And I daresay it's better than the original....more

title: A Confederacy of Dunces: A Novel
author: Toole, John Kennedy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: On so many occasions while reading A Confederacy of Dunces, I found myself laughing uproariously at the antics of Ignatius Reilly. This mad farce is wOn so many occasions while reading A Confederacy of Dunces, I found myself laughing uproariously at the antics of Ignatius Reilly. This mad farce is wildly entertaining. It is not a perfect novel, however: the scenes where Ignatius is not present are, by and large, rather hum-drum, with the comedy definitely two or three notches below the level of that when Ignatius is present. But anytime Ignatius is front and center, the novel soars and reels with ridiculous hilarity.One scene that I cannot get out of my mind is Ignatius trying to capture a stray cat and stow it in the bun warmer of his hot dog cart. And there are so many more madcap escapades involving this giant, bloviating, over-educated, pedantic mama's boy. A Confederacy of Dunces is a gem.I was actually quite surprised by how much I enjoyed this novel. I picked up A Confederacy of Dunces a decade or so ago and could not get past the first ten pages. I thought it was ridiculous and insipid. Anytime I read something referencing A Confederacy of Dunces, I would scowl, thinking what a terrible novel it was. Last week, however, a book podcaster claimed A Confederacy of Dunces was a much better comic adventure than Don Quixote, which I immensely enjoyed, so I decided to give A Confederacy of Dunces a second chance, and I am glad that I did. Now, is A Confederacy of Dunces as good as Don Quixote? No, it is not. It isn't even as good as America's greatest comic novels, Huckleberry Finn and Catch-22, but it is still a masterpiece of farce and comedy....more

title: The Adventures of Augie March
author: Bellow, Saul
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Saul Bellow definitely has a way with words. He writes bold, bombastic sentences that run away with themselves in long lists and rambling tangents thaSaul Bellow definitely has a way with words. He writes bold, bombastic sentences that run away with themselves in long lists and rambling tangents that sometimes require re-reading a few times to comprehend. That was my favorite part of this novel: savoring some of Bellow's magnificent sentences.This novel is the story of the eponymous Augie March. Augie is a good guy, a likable character, stumbling from one job to another and one woman to another, trying to make his way in the world. Throughout the novel, he ruminates on life and existence and fears he isn't living up to his potential, but he presses on, trying to find his dream and live it.The writing and the characterization here are brilliant, but there is not really much plot--just pericopes from Augie's life. While I appreciate Bellow's talent, this novel did not move me at all. And while Augie is a well drawn, fully realized character, he is not a character that I came to care all that much about. There aren't any broad themes in this novel that I found compelling. There is nothing really to sink your teeth into in this novel: it's just a novel about a guy's life. It is certainly well written, and the guy is an interesting guy in many ways, but the story of Augie March, at least for me, is not all that memorable....more

ALERT************************SPOILER ALERT************************SPOILER ALERT************************SPOILER ALERT************************SPOILER ALERT************************SPOILER ALERT************So, here's the plot hole: in 1979, Catherine Clare is bludgeoned to death with an ax while her toddler daughter, Franny, sleeps in the next room. The primary suspect is her husband, George, and everything in the novel points to George being the murderer. The police can never locate any solid evidence, so George is never charged. Near the end, the novel skips ahead 25 years to 2004. The house where the murder took place could not be sold for this quarter of a century, but it finally does sell to some buyers unaware of its bloody history. The real estate agent who sells the murder house tracks down Franny, who is now in medical school, and she asks Franny if she wants to come clean out the house before the new owners move in, and Franny does.As Franny is exploring the house, she finds a heart-shaped Valentine's chocolate box sitting on a book shelf in plain sight. Curious, she opens the box. It is filled with letters that Catherine had written but never sent--mainly to Catherine's own mother but also to her sister and even to God. In these never sent letters, Catherine writes that her husband is "psychotic" and her "adversary," that she plans to leave her husband, and in a letter dated the very day before the murder, that if anything should ever happen to her, ". . . don't assume it was an accident."Why the police never found this box is never explained. It seems incredible that the police would not have done a thorough search of the house and found these letters. When I got to this part of the novel, I kept thinking that there must be a catch or something that I was missing. Because the novel is also a bit of a ghost story, I thought that maybe, somehow, Catherine's ghost had kept the letters hidden for all these years and only brought them out of some mystical ghost world and back to the material world when Franny arrived. However, the novel does not even imply that this is the case, and Catherine hates George, so it makes no sense that her ghost would have kept the letters hidden from the police.I simply cannot understand how this plot hole made its way into this book because the author is, otherwise, extremely talented, but the ending betrays the rest of the story....more

review: The characters are superficial and undeveloped, and most of them are not likable. Even the protagonist, who is not unlikable, is still not someone thaThe characters are superficial and undeveloped, and most of them are not likable. Even the protagonist, who is not unlikable, is still not someone that the novel makes us really care about.There is a toddler character who is constantly saying things that we are supposed to find cute and adorable but that, instead, sound ridiculous and false. For example, at one point, the child says to her mother with no prompting and for no apparent reason, "Bees don't like when you do gymnastics on they's [sic} heads" (page 217). This line as well as much of the dialogue throughout sounds forced and synthetic. The characters in this novel do not talk and rarely even act like real people. This novel is full of stereotyped characters talking in stereotyped fashion; it lacks genuineness.The main plot point, though, is intriguing, so this novel isn't all bad. It's a debut effort, and the author shows some talent with plotting (although, even here, the plot takes too long to develop), so there is a possibility that after a bit more time to mature as a writer, this author could produce something of much better quality....more

title: The Ungrateful Refugee
author: Nayeri, Dina*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Everyone needs to read this book. For so many of us, refugees conjure faceless masses huddled in tent cities and filthy camps. In an age of growing naEveryone needs to read this book. For so many of us, refugees conjure faceless masses huddled in tent cities and filthy camps. In an age of growing nativism, we must acknowledge that every refugee is a person. When we hear their stories, we give faces to those faceless masses. We come to see that refugees deserve the same chance at life as anyone else, and if they want to take that chance in Europe or the US or Canada, we in the West should welcome them.That is why this book is important. It gives us the stories of refugees. It forces us to confront our privilege and ask why refugees do not deserve the same opportunities that we have. Refugees do not owe us their gratitude; they do not owe us anything; however, if we in the West want to live up to the standards of morality set by our greatest philosophers and religious and ethical teachers, then we must embrace refugees and welcome them in their flight from persecution, torture, poverty, suffering, and death....more

review: The first half of this book, which focuses mainly on Apollo Kagwa and his life, is a great family drama. I was completely caught up in and loved the sThe first half of this book, which focuses mainly on Apollo Kagwa and his life, is a great family drama. I was completely caught up in and loved the story of Apollo, of his parents, of his childhood, of his career, of his courtship of and marriage to Emma, and of his life as a father to baby Brian.When the changeling aspect of the story comes into play in the second half, however, the story loses its grounding and veers into the nearly ridiculous, even granting the allowances we make for fiction. I was still interested and wanted to see how the story would end, but I was very disappointed with how the seriousness and weight of the drama was shunted aside in the latter half. Seeing how well written the first half of the book was, I have no doubt that Victor LaValle, who is certainly a talented author, could have still told the changeling story in a fashion more tonally consistent with the first half. But, then again, who am I to question an artist's choice? All I can say is that I think this book had the potential to be great, but, in the end, it was just average....more

title: An Anonymous Girl
author: Hendricks, Greer*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Do you want to read a novel about New York City elites and their extravagant lifestyles? A novel about beautiful people and their beautiful people proDo you want to read a novel about New York City elites and their extravagant lifestyles? A novel about beautiful people and their beautiful people problems? Are you curious about all of the wonderful clothes and cars and wines and other luxuries that the wealthy enjoy? Well, then, my friend, this novel is tailor-made for you. Unless you also like a realistic plot and characters who resemble actual human beings in your stories--in which case, maybe give this a pass. I'm sorry. That's probably harsh. We all have our own individual taste. Some people might love this novel for very good reasons. It was not, however, my cup of tea.Several of my friends on Goodreads have given rave s to this novel, so I was hopeful that it would be great. Alas, it was not. I started to put it down at page 50, but my friends’ positive comments inspired me keep going. But by page 135, I couldn’t take it anymore. This novel is so utterly vapid that I wanted to stab myself in the eyes so that I would not have to read any more of its horrid prose or endure any more of its awful, amateurish storytelling.I’ll give a couple of examples, among far too many in only the first third of this novel, of why I so very much disliked An Anonymous Girl--at least those first 135 pages of it. Would it have gotten better had I finished it? Possibly, but I doubt it.At one point in this inane novel, Dr. Shields, ostensibly a highly educated and extremely intelligent university professor and mental health counselor, draws the following conclusion from a highly unethical experiment that she is running:“It is clear that not all men are susceptible to the attention of a beautiful young woman.”She had to run an experiment--one that runs afoul of the most fundamental principles of her field--to learn that not all men can be seduced by beautiful young women. An academic and a mental health professional had not already learned this not only from her studies and work but just from general life experience? Really? Are you kidding me? Another distasteful element in An Anonymous Girl is how it continually references all of the amenities that the rich enjoy in life. The authors revel in giving us details about the extravagant lifestyle of Dr. Shields, who seems able to afford a life of luxury that is not commensurate with her position as a college professor and mental health counselor. Consider the following:“An intimate location, the townhouse we once shared, is selected to eliminate outside distractions, such as an overbearing waiter or a boisterous party of six at the next table. The menu was carefully curated: a bottle of Dom Perignon, the same vintage served at our engagement party; Melpeques oysters; a rack of lamb; creamed spinach; oven-roasted baby potatoes with rosemary. For dessert, a variation of Thomas’s preferred sweet: chocolate torte.Traditionally, the torte is purchased at a patisserie on West Tenth Street. For tonight‘s meal, however, the ingredients have been procured from two separate gourmet markets.”If you’ve ever eaten a chocolate torte or just looked at a recipe, you know that you don’t have to go to two separate gourmet stores to get the ingredients. You can easily find all of the ingredients at any grocery store. If you were a snooty rich person, maybe you would buy them at a gourmet store, but you would certainly not need to go to two different gourmet stores. This type of stupid pandering to our idea of what life for the rich is like is nauseating—though it would be less so if such and similar passages were not found on almost every other page.I could go on with this  or with this book, but there are so many things in life that would be more enjoyable than continuing to read this drivel or to discuss it—like clipping my toenails or mopping my kitchen floor...more

title: In the Dream House
author: Machado, Carmen Maria*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is the best memoir I've read since Tara Westover's Educated. I found myself utterly surprised to be so engaged by this memoir about a toxic, abusThis is the best memoir I've read since Tara Westover's Educated. I found myself utterly surprised to be so engaged by this memoir about a toxic, abusive relationship. Why do I find this personal story so fascinating? Am I titillated by the horrifying details of the psychological and emotional abuse? Am I just curious about something so alien (a toxic relationship) to me? Am I baffled that such an intelligent, educated, strong woman could be the subject of such abuse and how she could put up with it for so long? I can't say for sure. I can say that I am repulsed and saddened by what Carmen Maria Machado endured at the hands of her abusive partner. No one should be treated as she was, yet the terrible truth is that far too many people are.In the Dream House reads like a thriller, like a game of cat-and-mouse, and we are definitely on the side of the mouse here. It's a compelling, informative, and thought-provoking dive into how abusive relationships play out. It is often emotionally overwhelming, moving me to tears on several occasions. While In the Dream House makes me grieve for everyone suffering in abusive relationships, it also makes me so very grateful that I have a healthy, loving relationship....more

review: Recursion takes the time travel novel to new territory as Blake Crouch devises a time travel method that, to my knowledge, has never before been broacRecursion takes the time travel novel to new territory as Blake Crouch devises a time travel method that, to my knowledge, has never before been broached. Crouch's approach to time travel is innovative, ingenious, and--unlike many other time travel novels--rigorously logical such that it is not subject to the Grandfather Paradox and similar time travel problems. Now, this is not to say that the time travel envisioned in Recursion seems likely to be feasible; it doesn't, but this is a work of fiction, so I'm not going to worry about how feasible this time travel mechanism is.Recursion, though, is not perfect: the first quarter is a bit slow, and the resolution is too easy and isn't fully consistent with the science of the time travel in this novel. Perhaps I should say not that the ending is not consistent with the science of the rest of the novel but that the ending is more of a deus ex machina that fails to fully account for why it works. Nevertheless, overall, I found this novel very well crafted and loved the ideas that it plays with....more

review: If I could send a message into the past to myself last week when I started this novel, it would be: "Don't waste your time on The Starless Sea."The StIf I could send a message into the past to myself last week when I started this novel, it would be: "Don't waste your time on The Starless Sea."The Starless Sea begins with great promise and then utterly fails to live up to that promise. Beyond the first third of this novel, reading it became a chore. I had to force myself to traipse through the latter two thirds. It was not remotely enjoyable. I adored Erin Morgenstern's first novel, The Night Circus, so I know that she is a talented writer who can spin a good yarn. The Starless Sea, however, is not good; it is an excruciatingly disappointing follow up to The Night Circus.The character development in The Starless Sea is minimal to non-existent. Despite being almost 500 pages, the novel fails to give much personality to its protagonist, Zachary, and even less to the supporting cast. We know that Zachary is a somewhat reserved, bookish video game fanatic, but not much beyond that; the novel simply does not take the time to flesh out his character. Because the characters are so flat, I didn't care about any of them. I was not invested in their stories or their fate, both of which, stories and fate, are major themes in the novel.And the love story between Zachary and Dorian did not work at all because we know almost nothing about them and can see no reason for them to fall in love. They basically fall in love at first sight with the novel never showing us why, beyond a physical attraction, they are so strongly attracted to each other. The love story lacks credibility. Again, I found myself not caring at all about this romance between our protagonist and his love interest.As poor as the character development is, the plot is even worse. This novel aspires to metafiction, to being a story about stories. It spins out multiple stories within the larger frame story that all relate back to each other and to the metanarrative, but it is all very convoluted--and not in a good way. Being convoluted is not necessarily a bad thing: some novels intricately weave and entwine multiple stories that inter-connect and loop back together such that we can appreciate the bigger picture because of the fine detail work. With The Starless Sea, though, the multiple storylines create more of a Pollack-like chaos than anything remotely beautiful.This novel is a mess. It is very beautifully written and has a wealth of great ideas, but the execution fails to due justice to the prose. Were it not for the quality of Morgenstern's writing, I would have rated this novel as one star. I was so relieved to finish this novel and be able to move on to something that will, I hope, be good....more

review: Snarky :I could have done with less kitten murder. Man, oh, man, does Robinson Crusoe murder a lot of kittens. Oh, also, Robinson Crusoe not orgSnarky :I could have done with less kitten murder. Man, oh, man, does Robinson Crusoe murder a lot of kittens. Oh, also, Robinson Crusoe not organizing slave trading and not being a racist would have been nice. But it was the 1600s. Slavery and kitten-murdering were apparently fine and dandy with many Europeans.Non-snarky :Despite the clunkiness of the 18th-century language to modern ears (the novel was first published in 1719), Robinson Crusoe is still a fairly easy read. I found the sections describing Robinson Crusoe's adventures and misadventures engaging and enjoyed the sections describing how he made a life for himself on the island where he was shipwrecked, but overall, the narrative structure seemed rather haphazard, and the novel is replete with racism and Eurocentrism with Crusoe himself, in the early part of the novel, setting up a shipping expedition to bring slaves from Africa to Brazil, and the novel takes it for granted that Christianity is the only true religion. To his credit, Crusoe is at least somewhat self-aware in reflecting how unjust it seems that the "pagans" of the Caribbean were not fortunate enough to have received the revelation of the Christian religion as did the Europeans, but he is still very much a man of his time.If Robinson Crusoe weren't among the earliest novels to be published and find widespread success, I don't think it would enjoy the reputation that it does today as it has little literary heft, is not particularly well written, and is more akin to Treasure Island than to a truly great work of literature like, for example, Moby Dick....more

review: Most of us fortunate enough not to have suffered sexual harassment have no idea what it is really like to experience being harassed and stalked by somMost of us fortunate enough not to have suffered sexual harassment have no idea what it is really like to experience being harassed and stalked by someone in a position of power over us. This memoir provides an account of that experience. Donna Freitas details the psychological, emotional, and spiritual trauma that she endured at the hands of her harasser, and she does so in sharply descriptive prose that brings her suffering starkly to life.This memoir will enrage you: you will be angry with her harasser and angry with the institution that further abused her, and you will be angry as you consider the multitudes of women who have been similarly assaulted and abused and mistreated by men--many of those women, like Donna Freitas, never truly receiving any justice. Yet you will also celebrate Donna Freitas for her courage in telling her story. This must have been a very difficult book for her to write, and she should be lauded for her effort in bringing her story to light as it shows precisely how atrocious and dehumanizing sexual harassment is....more

review: Walter Mosley has given us a thriller that is also an analysis of epistemology and the philosophy of history. It's a novel that asks how we know what Walter Mosley has given us a thriller that is also an analysis of epistemology and the philosophy of history. It's a novel that asks how we know what we know, how we do history, and whether the history that we study and think that we know is reliable. These ideas are examined through the lens of the academic career of the protagonist, the eponymous John Woman, a man who has changed his identity and is in hiding. The traditional thriller aspects of the novel are well done; the dialogue is crisp and interesting as John Woman channels Socrates, interrogating his students and their assumptions in witty, fruitful exchanges; and it is very interesting to see John Woman's ideas, which are likely familiar to anyone with a cursory knowledge of epistemology and philosophy, applied to a real word situation--namely that of John Woman. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Owen's voice and tiny stature. Owen as the tragic pinch hitter in a little league game. Owen as the hilarious Baby Jesus in the Episcopalian nativity Owen's voice and tiny stature. Owen as the tragic pinch hitter in a little league game. Owen as the hilarious Baby Jesus in the Episcopalian nativity play. Owen as the terrifying Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come in the stage production of A Christmas Carol. Owen as the boy and man of unwavering faith. Owen as a prophet. Owen as the caustic, satirical columnist and brilliant prankster at Gravesend Academy. Owen as a friend beyond compare. Owen as a hero. Jane Austen's Elizabeth Bennett. Charles Dickens's David Copperfield and Pip. Mark Twain's Huckleberry Finn. Fyodor Dostoevsky's Raskolnikov. To this list of literary characters who are so powerfully drawn and so intriguing that they sear themselves into our memories, we must add John Irving's Owen Meany. We don't need an overarching plot (though we do get one in A Prayer for Owen Meany) because Owen is such a unique, inherently fascinating character that simply following the everyday events in his life is more than enough to keep us turning the pages in anticipation.I laughed throughout this novel at Owen's misadventures, and even though Irving makes it fairly clear what direction the narrative will take, I was still in tears as it ended. I loved the theological reflections of the novel as Owen and John (Owen's best friend and also the narrator of this novel) struggled with their religious faith and questions of fate and divine intervention. Most of all, I fell in love with Owen Meany. I wish I knew someone like Owen Meany. While I have very many good friends, I wish I had a friend like Owen Meany. I loved spending time with this character, and having finished this novel, I am sad to say good-bye to Owen Meany. I picked up A Prayer for Owen Meany after seeing it on several lists of the 100 greatest novels of the twentieth century. I would put it in the top 10, maybe even the top 5, of the novels of the twentieth century. I love this novel. I love Owen Meany....more

title: Gone with the Wind
author: Mitchell, Margaret
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The elephant in the room with Gone with the Wind is its overt racism, and any  of the novel would be incomplete if it did not address this matteThe elephant in the room with Gone with the Wind is its overt racism, and any  of the novel would be incomplete if it did not address this matter. The novel is set in the South during the Civil War and Reconstruction, and its main characters are all white; as such, racism and white supremacy permeate the novel and inform much of what the characters think, say, and do. Of course, if the white Southerners were portrayed as anything other than racist (unless they were that rarest of rare birds: Southern abolitionists), the novel would not be true to those characters. Thus, a novel with the characters and setting of Gone with the Wind must, if it is to be credible, depict the unapologetic and even celebrated racism that was prevalent at the time. The problem with the racism in the novel, then, is not its honest portrayal of racism but rather the fundamental dishonesty of Margaret Mitchell in not portraying or even acknowledging the true horrors of slavery. Mitchell makes a few oblique references to slaves being whipped, to slave families being separated, to fugitive slaves being chased by hounds, and to slaves being sold to plantations in the Deep South where conditions are hinted at as being terrible, especially as compared to Tara, but apart from these few brief and dismissive references, Mitchell paints slavery as a largely benign institution and one that actually is good for slaves. This is the moral failing of the entire novel and of Margaret Mitchell: Gone with the Wind lies about slavery. Since slavery was fundamental to the Southern economy and to the white Southern culture and way of life as Mitchell clearly acknowledges, Mitchell's failure to be honest in her depiction of slavery is a sin against history and betrays the historical and cultural setting of her novel. Moreover, the novel depicts the Ku Klux Klan as a heroic organization which takes action only to right the wrongs committed by "uppity," "trashy," and criminal, in the eyes of the Klan, former slaves and not as the terrorist organization, murdering and lynching and burning property, that it was. Fictional novels, of course, don't have to be non-fictional accounts, but they must still be true to their setting and to their characters. And Gone with the Wind is not honest; it is a lie.Setting this important failure aside for a moment, we can look at its strengths: Mitchell has created two of the most powerful, memorable characters in all of literature in Scarlett O'Hara and Rhett Butler. Both are amoral, Machiavellian, and thoroughly yet blithely selfish. Still, somehow, Mitchell makes us care for these two horrible human beings. We never quite come to like them, but we do find ourselves concerned for them and their futures, and Mitchell's ability to create such vivid and villainous characters without causing us to hate them shows her genius. It is also remarkable that we are able to maintain our interest in the stories of the lives of these two for over 1,000 pages; they never bore us: we simply cannot get enough of their sordid lives.To Mitchell's credit, she remains true to her characters throughout: there are no happy endings here. In the end, Gone with the Wind is bleak, even nihilistic. The wicked prosper, but even in their prospering, they are not happy. Reading this novel is not enjoyable, and the ending is not sad but dismal and cold. But this novel is not a tragedy: these aren't good people who go astray or fall from grace; they are amoral and oftentimes evil people, and they live in a world where what is sown is not reaped. Their evil goes largely unpunished, though they do suffer tragic losses with the deaths of Bonnie and Melanie. In this regard, the novel is, for once, honest.As I reflected on how to rate Gone with the Wind, I wanted to be honest about its literary merits and did not want my disgust at the lies it tells about slavery to affect my aesthetic judgment. But then I thought: the fact that this novel is fundamentally dishonest about slavery cannot be separated from its literary merits. If someone were to write a story about lower- and mid-level Nazi officials and their families and try to paint a rosy picture of the Holocaust, we would, even if the novel were brilliantly written, not be able to overlook the insult to the millions murdered in the Holocaust nor set aside such a grand distortion of history. Similarly with Gone with the Wind, we cannot give Mitchell a pass in her lying about slavery. She has written a novel that glosses over and even defends one of the greatest atrocities in human history. Were it not for this colossal failure, I would have rated this novel at four-stars based on the strong characters and the story-telling, but I cannot get past the enormous and atrociously evil lie that this novel tells. The moral failing of this novel cannot help but bleed into my aesthetic assessment: any work of art that is dismissive of slavery, the Holocaust, genocide, the rape and murder of children, and other such atrocities cannot be anything other than an artistic failure. And so despite having two of the most compelling characters in the history of literature, Gone with the Wind is a vilely deceitful, despicable, terrible novel....more

review: As I was perusing various lists of the best books of the 2000s, I noticed that Outline was in the top 10 or top 20 on several lists, and so I picked iAs I was perusing various lists of the best books of the 2000s, I noticed that Outline was in the top 10 or top 20 on several lists, and so I picked it up at my local library.While I'd be hard pressed to place it in my top 20 books of the 2000s, I do have to say that Outline is very a good book: the prose is graceful, understated and lovely. The plot is sparse: while there is an overall narrative--we follow the narrator, Faye, as she flies from her home in England to Athens, where she teaches a writing course to the local Greeks--the novel functions more as a series of short (sometimes very short) stories about Faye's friends, her students, and the people that she meets. These individuals tend to lead fairly typical lives, but Cusk manages to make the typical quite fascinating.I also liked that, at about 250 pages, I was able to breeze through Outline very quickly. It's a serious novel but not one that is overly dense. Overall, I don't think Outline lives up to the literary hype, but it is nevertheless a solid piece of fiction....more

review: The characterization is wonderful, and the first half of the novel is excellent. The second half seemed to drag and lose steam; it just went on for toThe characterization is wonderful, and the first half of the novel is excellent. The second half seemed to drag and lose steam; it just went on for too long: this is a 640-page novel that, with some tight editing, could have been 500 pages without losing much substance. The plot is also somewhat desultory and meandering. Had the second half been more engaging and the plot better structured, this would have been a 4-star or possibly even a 5-star novel for me. I picked up this novel to read for two reasons: I loved Chabon's The Yiddish Policemen's Union, and The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay is on many lists of the top novels (and at the top of several of those lists) published in the 2000s. I don't think it is as good as The Yiddish Policemen's Union, and I would not rank it even in the top 30 novels of the 2000s. It is good, well-written novel, but for me, it does not live up to the hype of being one of the great American novels of the past two decades....more

title: The Uninhabitable Earth: Life After Warming
author: Wallace-Wells, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sobering. We have all been sleeping. This book is an ear-shattering alarm.The apocalypse that I heard about growing up in a fundamentalist religious hSobering. We have all been sleeping. This book is an ear-shattering alarm.The apocalypse that I heard about growing up in a fundamentalist religious household is coming. But it’s not the apocalypse of which my fellow believers and I were warned. And unless God or Jesus or benevolent aliens intervene, we will all drink the wine of the grapes of wrath of climate change. If you care about the future not only of your own old age but the future of your children and your children’s children, you must read this book. We need to pull our heads out of the sand and face the harsh and painful reality: climate change is real, and it is changing our world much for the worse. And that horrifying change is coming unbelievably quickly.By the year 2050, the world as we know it will likely be radically reshaped due to the effects of climate change. Many of the world’s coastal cities will be underwater. Hundreds of millions and perhaps even billions of people will be displaced due to the oceans encroaching into our coastal cities, creating migration crises that make crises like the ones we are currently seeing at the US-Mexico border seem trifling.The heat will have devastating effects on agriculture: crop yields will likely plunge, leading to mass starvations. Water will become the new oil in a world plagued by drought. Not only will we humans not have enough water to meet our needs for drinking water and for sanitation, but we will not have enough water for agriculture, further exacerbating the starvation crisis.These changes to our water supply and agricultural systems as well as the destruction of our coastal cities will have profound repercussions politically and economically. We will likely see economic downturns that make the Great Depression look like a minor economic setback. With agriculture and infrastructure and economies in shambles, existing political power structures will fall. The world will be ripe for the rise of authoritarianism and violent revolutions. Contemporary capitalism and neo-liberalism will be dead.All of this could happen very easily by 2050. We could possibly avoid our collective doom if we make radical changes immediately, but the changes would require huge sacrifices here and now, changes that we do not seem to have the political will to make. If we do not change, the consequences for our lives and the lives of the next generations will unquestionably be deadly.Our selfishness and shortsightedness, alas, will likely keep us from changing. We are destroying our world for human habitation, and our collective inaction shows that we really do not care....more

review: I picked up The Last Samurai after seeing it show up on several different lists as the best novel published in the 2000s (for example, see here: httpsI picked up The Last Samurai after seeing it show up on several different lists as the best novel published in the 2000s (for example, see here: https://www.vulture.com/article/best-...). (Since it was published in 2000, it seems that the 2000s, at least in those ers opinions, peaked early.) Now, is it the best novel of the 2000s? I would have to say, "No," but I still think it's very good--a brilliant, unique literary romp. Helen DeWitt writes like no other writer I've encountered. She spins quite a yarn--and a very tangled yarn of stories within stories and adjacent to other stories and tangentially connected to those stories and piled up next to and twisted around still more stories, all of which somehow tie into the main plot of a child prodigy trying to find the father that his mother won't tell him about with the great Kurosawa film Seven Samurai always haunting the background. DeWitt's prose dazzles and delights. Her imagination is boundless and her intellect astounding. She writes with warmth and heart but without being sentimental. I had no idea what I was getting into when I picked up this novel other than that it was supposed to be very good. What I found was a novel unlike any I had ever read, and one that I rather enjoyed....more
