title: The Razor’s Edge
author: Maugham, W. Somerset
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The prose is brilliant--educated, witty, graceful; the characterization, realistic but at a sufficient remove to allow the reader to objectively assesThe prose is brilliant--educated, witty, graceful; the characterization, realistic but at a sufficient remove to allow the reader to objectively assess the players. The Razor's Edge is an almost haphazard biography of Larry Darrell told through several pericopes, each separated by a number of months or years. The narrator, who identifies himself as W. Somerset Maugham, paints Larry's portrait largely through his interactions with his friends--many of whose stories slightly usurp Larry's--and all of whom are also in the narrator's circle, with the narrator himself being a friend of Larry. We follow Larry's life over the course of about 20 years, and it is something of a spiritual and philosophical journey as Larry seeks to answer the ultimate questions of existence.My favorite section of the novel is a long conversation towards the end in which Larry and the narrator discuss Larry's struggle with the problem of evil and how, during his travels in India, he found, to some extent, an answer in Hinduism. Larry's discourse is wise, well informed, honest, frank, and tender. It's a passage that, I think, probably inspired a lot of young people in the 1950s and 1960s (the novel was first published in 1943) to look to Eastern religions when they found themselves dissatisfied with the Western religious and philosophical tradition.Maugham writes with a light touch about deeply important matters without being preachy or zealous. He questions, though does not indict, the economic, religious, and philosophical traditions of the West not through diatribe but through the events in the lives of his characters. And he tells a pretty good story, though not one with a lot of action, while he is at it....more

title: A Woman Is No Man
author: Rum, Etaf*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A Woman Is No Man is the best book of 2019. Now, I haven't read all the books published in 2019. In fact, it's only April of 2019, so there are many bA Woman Is No Man is the best book of 2019. Now, I haven't read all the books published in 2019. In fact, it's only April of 2019, so there are many books yet to be published in 2019. But I feel very confident in asserting that A Woman Is No Man is now--and will still be by the end of the year--the best book of 2019.My god! What an amazing story! A story of family secrets--dark secrets that destroy lives but also, when exposed to the light, bring a measure of redemption. A story of misogyny and domestic violence and of women and girls fighting to overcome the soul-destroying, spirit-crushing power of patriarchy. A story of courage and cowardice, of despair and hope. A story of women submitting to and being complicit in the worst excesses of sexism. And a story of women standing up to and defying the patriarchal power structure.This novel left me in tears on many occasions. Left me gasping in horror and shock. Left me crying out to God for justice. Left me rejoicing when the women and girls prevailed. Left me reeling with grief at what they suffered. This is a story of three generations of Palestinian American women: Fareeda, the matriarch of her family; Isra, Fareeda's daughter-in-law; Sarah, Fareeda's daughter; and Deya, Isra's daughter and Fareeda's granddaughter and Sarah's niece. The men in the family also have prominent roles, but the women dominate the storyline, and all of the characters are richly drawn and exceedingly complex. These are not typical fictional characters who flit through the readers' mind, only to be forgotten when the book is finished. These women will stay with me and stay with me and stay with me and stay with me. This is an unforgettable story with characters who take on a life beyond the pages of this novel, who incarnate themselves in the minds of the readers; they are the word become flesh.If you could read only one book in 2019, it should be A Woman Is No Man. This is a thematically rich novel with a complex, beautifully composed narrative supported by, as I think I might have already mentioned, truly remarkable characters. This book carried lifted me to the heights of the heavens--and then dropped me. It battered me, shattered me, bruised me, and broke me. And then it tended my wounds, restored my hope, healed me. While I was aghast at and in despair over many of the things I witnessed in the book, I absolutely adored this book. I can't remember a novel having such an impact on me since Hanya Yanagihara's A Little Life, which I loved, and I love A Woman Is No Man as much as Yanagihara's brilliant novel.Bravo, Etaf Rum! Bravo! Bravissimo! Bravissimo! You have written a truly great novel! Thank you, Etaf Rum, for sharing this story with the world! ...more

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Dostoevsky, Fyodor
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I first read Crime and Punishment twenty-odd years ago, I loved it. I would have rated it five stars. On re-reading it, however, I find myself leWhen I first read Crime and Punishment twenty-odd years ago, I loved it. I would have rated it five stars. On re-reading it, however, I find myself less impressed. Now, this is not to say it is a bad novel; it is not. There are flashes of genius throughout, especially in the passages on moral philosophy, from which Nietzsche drew great inspiration for his concept of the Übermensch. The interactions between Raskolnikov and police detective Porfiry Petrovich show Dostoevsky at his best with brilliant, engaging dialogue and a fascinating dissection of the human psyche. There is much to like in this novel.The primary reason that I liked Crime and Punishment less on this second read is that Raskolnikov is such a horrible, unlikable character. It's not just that he murders the miserly pawnbroker and her innocent sister, though this issue looms larger for me this time around, but it's also that Raskolnikov is a petty, jealous, sniveling, self-centered, lazy, high-strung, contemptuous person. Even had he not murdered the two women, there would be little to like about him. It's no wonder that, apart from Razumihin, he has no real friends, and he is constantly in danger of alienating even Razumihin. He continually antagonizes everyone in his life--from Sonia, his mother, his sister, and Razumihin, on the friendly side, to the police and Svidrigailov and his doctor and his sister's would-be suitor, on the more unfriendly side. When other characters try to help him, he is, as a matter of course, dismissive and ungrateful. And worst of all, he's weak, lacking all convictions and constantly blown about by whims. After the murders, he lacks sufficient constitution to follow his own convictions about why he committed the crime and how he should respond to his actions. Raskolnikov doesn't possess the strength of character to carry this novel.Additionally, the novel has so many side-plots that, while they do contribute to the overall narrative, take up far too much time. It seems fairly obvious that Dostoevsky had no editor, and he desperately could have used one. My copy of this novel is 629 pages, and I would estimate that a good editor could have cut the novel by about a third, down to 400 pages, give or take 30 pages, without losing any of the novel's philosophical or narrative force.Crime and Punishment is a a good novel, but it is not great. I'm almost afraid to go back and re-read my other favorites of Dostoevsky, The Brothers Karamazov and The Possessed, as I would hate to find that they, too, don't hold up. Prior to re-reading Crime and Punishment, I would have placed it in my top ten favorite novels of all time. Now, I don't think I'd even place it in my top one hundred. But, again, it's not a bad novel: it certainly has had a tremendous influence on many great thinkers, Nietzsche especially, and writers, proffering some profound insights into psychology and moral philosophy, but from a literary perspective, it is too problematic, too unpolished to be counted among the world's greatest novels....more

title: The Other Americans
author: Lalami, Laila*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At the center of this novel is a hit-and-run incident that takes a man's life: was it just an accident, was it reckless driving, or was it perhaps murAt the center of this novel is a hit-and-run incident that takes a man's life: was it just an accident, was it reckless driving, or was it perhaps murder?But The Other Americans is so much more than this mystery. It is a character study of all the people connected to the hit-and-run: the victim himself, the victim's family, the local community where the hit-and-run occurred, the perpetrator and the perpetrator's family, and the police detective who investigates; each of these individuals has a fascinating story in her or his own right--enough of story, in fact, that I would read an entire novel just centered on any one of these characters.The novel also tackles the issues of race and religious minorities in rural America. It is not overtly preachy but instead addresses these issues through the lives of the characters. It doesn't tell us about what bigotry is like but rather shows it to us firsthand through the characters' experiences.The central mystery itself is handled with care: there are a few red herrings here and there, enough to keep the reader a bit off balance, and then just when you think everything is settled and the novel is winding down to a quiet, anticlimactic ending, the novel delivers a surprise, but it's not a crazy twist and makes complete sense, so it's a surprise that provides the perfect mix of unexpectedness and narrative satisfaction.The Other Americans is a subtle, quiet mystery with a great cast of characters, and it is exceptionally well written....more

title: The Trial of Lizzie Borden
author: Robertson, Cara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Prior to reading this fascinating, extraordinarily well researched history of the murders of Lizzie Borden's father and step-mother and the subsequentPrior to reading this fascinating, extraordinarily well researched history of the murders of Lizzie Borden's father and step-mother and the subsequent trial, my familiarity with the case was basically limited to the infamous schoolyard rhyme:Lizzie Borden took an axeAnd gave her mother forty whacksWhen she saw what she had doneShe gave her father forty-oneGoing into this book, I honestly could not recall if Borden had been found guilty at her trial, so I decided that I would try to approach the case as objectively as possible: in fact, I decided to read the book as if I were myself a member of the jury and then, after ing all of the evidence, decide whether I would have cast a vote for conviction or acquittal. Happily for my endeavor, the book does not reveal the final verdict until near the end. Cara Robertson fully situates us in the time (1892) and place (Fall River, Massachusetts), providing us with a good grasp of the cultural and social environment in which Lizzie Borden lived. Robertson walks us through all that we know about the murders--the timeline on the day of the murders, how the murders were carried out, the reactions and statements of Lizzie as well as of the first people on the scene of the crime, the police investigation, the arrest of Lizzie, the pre-trial hearings, and finally the trial itself, detailing meticulously the evidence presented by both the state and the defense as well as the brilliant rhetorical arguments made by the attorneys on both sides.Thus, by the time Robertson has presented all of the evidence and walked us step-by-step through the trial (all aspects of which are highly engaging reading), I felt like I had a solid grasp of all of the factors in question such that I could render my verdict. Thus, I asked myself, "Can I say, beyond a reasonable doubt, that Lizzie Borden murdered her father and her step-mother?" Based on all of the evidence (and Robertson gives us every last piece of information presented at the trial and even more), I have to say that I think Lizzie probably did murder her father and step-mother; if pressed, I'd put the probability of her guilt at 80%. Of course, that means that there is a 20% likelihood that she did not murder her father and step-mother, and that's still a pretty significant possibility that Lizzie was not guilty. Thus, for me, there is certainly a reasonable doubt that Lizzie was guilty, and so my vote, as a juror, would have been not guilty, which is exactly the verdict rendered by the 12 white men who heard Lizzie Borden's case.It seems macabre to say this, but I thoroughly enjoyed this examination of one of the most famous--if not the most famous--axe murders in history. I learned a lot both about the case itself and about the time and place during which the murders took place. It was also (and, of course, I know this sounds terrible on many levels) a lot of fun to set myself up as a juror and to render my verdict....more

title: The Care and Feeding of Ravenously Hungry Girls
author: Gray, Anissa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Prior to reading The Care and Feeding of Ravenously Hungry Girls, I cannot remember the last time a book made me cry, but I burst into tears three timPrior to reading The Care and Feeding of Ravenously Hungry Girls, I cannot remember the last time a book made me cry, but I burst into tears three times while reading this book. Now, just because this novel moved me to tears does not necessarily mean it is a good novel, but it actually is a good novel--even a great novel. I loved and adored it.The Care and Feeding of Ravenously Hungry Girls is a family drama focusing on three sisters, one of whom has just gone to jail for financial crimes. The chapters move between first-person narration from the sisters interspersed with letters from the eldest sister's husband to his wife. We see not only how the eldest sister's crime has affected her younger sisters but also her daughters and the wider community, and we learn about other tensions and conflicts within this family that have been bubbling under, and occasionally boiling over, for years and even decades.And this story is told with one of the most amazing authorial voices I have encountered in quite some time: Anissa Gray's prose has that rarest of rare qualities wherein you don't feel like you're reading a book but rather that you are completely enveloped in the story. The dialogue never feels forced or manufactured. These three sisters are not fictional characters: they are real, living, breathing, human beings. Everything about Gray's prose is authentic and tangible, graspable, relatable.The Care and Feeding of Ravenously Hungry Girls deals with some difficult themes (child abuse, child neglect, eating disorders, infidelity, homophobia, poverty, crime) but does so without sensationalizing these issues and without vilifying anyone while still showing how harmful these things can be. The novel is also a story of forgiveness and redemption that draws heavily on religion but does so without being preachy and without caricaturing religion or religious people.I loved the experience of reading The Care and Feeding of Ravenously Hungry Girls. I loved the people I met in this novel. I loved the story that it told. I loved the beautiful writing. There is no question that this will be among my favorite books of 2019....more

title: Kindred
author: Butler, Octavia E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Kindred hooked me from the very beginning, and each time I had to put it down, it was with great reluctance, and when I would take it up again, it wasKindred hooked me from the very beginning, and each time I had to put it down, it was with great reluctance, and when I would take it up again, it was with barely contained anticipation to see what would happen next.I love the novel's protagonist, Dana. She is thrown into the strangest of situations (being transported back and forth in time by unknown forces), yet she responds calmly and rationally, taking steps to prepare herself for the antebellum world to which she continually jumps from her own time in 1976. She is not overwhelmed by panic. She is smart and pragmatic, and her sharp social skills enable her to navigate relatively safely a minefield of dangerous personalities. On top of everything else, she is kind, forgiving, and selfless. She's a great heroine whom we readers are rooting for from the very beginning.Rufus, the villain of the novel, is the best kind of villain: we are ambivalent towards him, unsure whether he is, at heart, good or evil. We meet him as a young boy, and we see that he has the potential to grow up to be a virtuous man, and in another era, he very well could have, but his father--who is distant but still, in his own way, loving--is cruel and beset with the worst prejudices of his time while his mother loves him deeply but is herself a jealous, ill-tempered woman. With such parents, we can sympathize with Rufus and understand why he does not become the man we hope that he would. Rufus is sometimes a very good man, sometimes wicked, earning our admiration one moment and our disgust and anger the next. Like Dana, we want to love him and want to see him embrace what he knows to be good and right, but we can never trust him and always fear him.The supporting characters are not mere props for Dana and Rufus but are well developed with intriguing narrative arcs of their own: Kevin, who endures his wife's strange tribulations and does all he can to help her; Alice, who is born free and suffers in her own unique way at the hands of Rufus; Sarah, the elder stateswoman and cook on the plantation; Carrie, Sarah's mute yet resourceful daughter; Nigel, Carrie's husband and Rufus's childhood friend who must often play peacemaker. All of these characters endear themselves to us and play vital roles in the narrative.Finally, Kindred is a time travel novel, making it a fascinating mix of historical fiction and science fiction. And one of things I most appreciate about the time travel element is that (view spoiler)[it is never explained. Octavia Butler presents the time travel as a given and makes no attempt to give it any scientific or even magical explanation. At first, we readers are, of course, curious about the how and why of the time travel, but that is really only a minor detail when compared to the main story, the relationship between Dana and Rufus; as such, Butler wastes no time trying explain the time travel, and the novel is all the better for it. This is the world she has created. We accept it and move on, allowing the story unfold on its own terms (hide spoiler)]. But what I appreciate even more is that this is a tale well told that kept me in suspense from beginning to end, eagerly consuming the pages as quickly as I could....more

title: The Forgotten Hours
author: Schumann, Katrin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Forgotten Hours could have easily been a 5-star read for me: it has a great premise and a solid, though noticeably underdeveloped, cast of charactThe Forgotten Hours could have easily been a 5-star read for me: it has a great premise and a solid, though noticeably underdeveloped, cast of characters. But it falls short of being a great novel because it reads more as melodrama than drama, and the narrative flow is often slow and stilted only to be interrupted by sudden, dramatic shifts that feel forced and salacious. In fleshing out the characters and the settings, the author draws on clichés, incorporates details that don't ring true, and writes dialogue that does not sound like the way people actually talk. As a result, The Forgotten Hours lacks the depth that its subject matter deserves. I can't help but think that a really good editor could have corrected these issues and turned this into a much better novel.Despite these criticisms, I did not think that this was a bad novel. I did enjoy reading The Forgotten Hours and found it, in many instances, quite captivating. It is this author's first work of fiction, and it is certainly a good effort. As she continues to write and develop her craft, I think she has the talent to produce much better work that this novel....more

review: No Exit is a textbook example of how to write a thriller: a perfect setting (five people trapped inside a rest stop in the mountains of Colarado), a gNo Exit is a textbook example of how to write a thriller: a perfect setting (five people trapped inside a rest stop in the mountains of Colarado), a great plot (one of those five, the protagonist, Darby, discovers a kidnapped child, Jay, locked in a cage in a van parked at the rest stop), solid characterization for a genre novel (Darby and Ashley are especially well drawn), numerous twists and turns and reversals (some that many readers will see coming, and some that many readers won't, but all still well done and entertaining), more than enough suspense to keep readers eagerly turning the pages, a quick and easy read but written in careful, professional prose, plenty of action and even gruesome gore (view spoiler)[Ed being shot and murdered with a nail gun, Sandi being murdered by having her neck cruelly broken by Ashley, Darby having her fingers smashed horrifically in a door and then having to saw them off to escape, Lars having his throat cut when Darby punches him in the throat with a Swiss army knife blade, and Ashley finally being subdued when young Jay shoots him in the face with his dead brother's gun (hide spoiler)] that is hard to read yet strangely fascinating, and a final twist (view spoiler)[in the final pages, it seems that everyone has died: the villains, Ashley and his brother Lars; the heroine, Darby; Ashley's less villainous accomplice, Sandi; and Sandi's innocent bystander cousin, Ed; however, in the last few paragraphs, we learn that Darby has survived (hide spoiler)] that brings the novel to a satisfying conclusion.No Exit is just a lot of fun--and also a lot of wincing at some of the brutal action....more

title: The Water Cure
author: Mackintosh, Sophie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This novel is a Yorgos Lanthimos film on the page. It is a strange, alien world with its own grammar and twisted logic. It is a world of humans whose This novel is a Yorgos Lanthimos film on the page. It is a strange, alien world with its own grammar and twisted logic. It is a world of humans whose behavior baffles and intrigues us. It is a tale of callous cruelty and tender love, of xenophobic fascination and filial impiety. And it is a parable on patriarchy and misogyny.The Water Cure gives us a world of mystery without answering any of our questions about the nature and origin of that world. The author, Sophie Mackintosh, is not myth-making or world-building. Mackintosh presents this strange world and lets us experience it and figure things out for ourselves. She spends no time telling, but rather, as a good writer should, showing. She respects our intelligence.Mackintosh paints harshness, brutality in stark, gray colors. There is pain and much suffering. But there is hope, though it is a dim and quavering hope.Mackintosh's characters are the flesh made word. Her sentences are potent and precise, meting out her adverbs and adjectives with thrift and consideration. She is a writer fully in command of her craft. The Water Cure makes an impression. It wounds the spirit and would, were it possible, puncture the skin. The characters live in an alien landscape and operate from a strange psychology, but we come to know them well, to see them as fellow travelers in our own world. Mackintosh's message is not subtle, so I won't spend anytime elaborating on it, but it is powerful all the same....more

title: Suicidal: Why We Kill Ourselves
author: Bering, Jesse*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: In this perceptive, sensitive study, Jesse Bering looks at suicide from all angles. He asks the philosophical and ethical questions surrounding it. HeIn this perceptive, sensitive study, Jesse Bering looks at suicide from all angles. He asks the philosophical and ethical questions surrounding it. He looks at it psychologically, from the mental health perspective. He examines the sociological and religious factors that impinge on suicide. He considers the practicalities of suicide--how access to tools that make suicide easier (guns, for example) affects suicide rates. He wrestles with the difficult questions about suicidal contagion--that is, whether some individuals are more likely to attempt suicide after exposure to suicide in literature, in film, or in the news. Then, moving beyond these academic analyses, Bering probes numerous individual stories of those who have attempted suicide or died by suicide. He quotes extensively from and reflects upon their journals and suicide notes, and he listens to and relates to his readers what their family members and friends have to say. To shed further light, he interviews mental health professionals who have worked with suicidal individuals and academics who have written and published extensively on suicide. Finally, he writes about his own struggles with suicidal ideation; this is a very personal book for Bering, and it's all the better for it.The final result is a fascinating, extremely informative, nuanced discussion of suicide. It is humane, thoughtful, wise, and kind. It offers no easy answers or definitive judgements, for there are none. This is a book that is going to stick with me and will, I think, with most readers....more

K. Rowling, but two have come close: Naomi Novik and Katherine Arden. I'm sad to see the end of the Winternight Trilogy but hopeful that Arden will create more magical worlds to share with us....more

title: Maid: Hard Work, Low Pay, and a Mother's Will to Survive
author: Land, Stephanie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Maid is Stephanie Land's candid memoir about her life as a single mother and domestic abuse survivor trying to claw her way out of abject poverty. MaiMaid is Stephanie Land's candid memoir about her life as a single mother and domestic abuse survivor trying to claw her way out of abject poverty. Maid relates Stephanie's continual struggle teetering on the brink of homelessness: any unexpected expense (medical bills for her sick child, a repair bill for her car, a snowstorm that prevents her from working, etc.) could mean that she couldn't pay rent, and she and her daughter would have nowhere to live. Her family support system is minimal, and she daily endures the stress of trying to scrape together enough money to keep a roof over her head and feed her daughter all while doing one of the most difficult and, at times, disgusting, of jobs: working as a maid.Stephanie's memoir, although entitled Maid, isn't primarily about what she did in this job--though that is an important component of this book. Maid, instead, is more a story of survival. It's a story that shows that, even if you work as hard as you can, you still can't always escape poverty. Maid is also a story about how society treats the poor: all too often, when we are not too busy ignoring the poor, we look down on them, hold them in contempt, and even ridicule them. We shame the poor because we don't understand why they are poor and why they can't escape poverty. This memoir remedies our ignorance and call us to account for our prejudice.Maid is an important book because it shows that society's tendency to blame the poor for their poverty is unjust. Many people who live in poverty, like Stephanie, work extremely hard, doing everything that they can to escape the soul-crushing grind of poverty. Stephanie's story forces us to confront the unpleasant reality that the American dream may not be obtainable for many Americans--regardless of how hard they work....more

title: The Annotated Frankenstein
author: Shelley, Mary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: ***There will be spoilers in this .***Frankenstein surprised me: having never read the book or watched any of the films, I was not expecting Vic***There will be spoilers in this .***Frankenstein surprised me: having never read the book or watched any of the films, I was not expecting Victor Frankenstein's creation (in popular culture usually referred to as either Frankenstein or as the monster, but the former is inaccurate and the latter pejorative, so I call him VFC) to be a lumbering, zombie-esque creature. Instead, VFC is a thoughtful, deeply sensitive, achingly lonely individual. We readers are appalled by the injustices that VFC suffers and the horrible treatment that he receives from humans. He does so much good--saving the life of a drowning child, helping Felix and Agatha and their father, quietly listening and reading to learn human language and to educate himself, trying to hide himself as he knows his appearance is frightful--and in the end his reward is being feared, hated, and hunted. So we understand his rage at Victor for abandoning his responsibility.VFC is not the villain of this novel. The villain is the sniveling, wavering, cowardly Victor. As Victor himself frequently laments, he is ultimately responsible for the deaths of William (Victor's younger brother), Justine (wrongfully accused and executed for William's murder), Clerval (Victor's best friend), Elizabeth (Victor's cousin and then wife), and even of Victor's father, who seems to die of heartbreak when Elizabeth, his beloved niece dies. Victor's narration of his story to Robert Walton aboard Walton's ship is a mix: Victor both rages against VFC and describes him constantly as a daemon, a vile and evil mistake while also lamenting his own error in creating VFC. But what Victor never does is admit his error in abandoning VFC: VFC was not created evil; the early scenes indicate that VFC is inherently good-natured but is corrupted by his experiences. Had Victor not shirked his responsibility and slowly introduced VFC into society, the novel would not have ended so tragically, with almost all of Victor's loved ones dead (except his other brother Ernest, whom Victor also seems to abandon when he pursues VFC into the Arctic, and this is particularly galling since Ernest is an orphan and further shows how weak-willed and self-centered Victor is) and with Victor himself dying and VFC presumably committing suicide.With the constant reference's to Milton's Paradise Lost, there is little question in my mind that Mary Shelley was consciously allegorizing the primal Jewish and Christian myth but re-shaping it: Victor is God, and his initial creation, VFC, is Adam, but in Shelley's narrative, there is no original sin--no temptation by an evil serpent due to Eve's (woman's) weakness and subsequent fall. The original sin is God's turning his back on his creation. The fall is God's fault, not Adam's and certainly not Eve's. Yes, humanity bears responsibility for many of its evils, but the ultimate source of the suffering and evil of the world is God. I'm not sure if Shelley herself was an atheist, but granted that she was married to a famous atheist, Percy Shelley, she was certainly not unsympathetic to atheism, and this comes through loud and clear in the novel. Frankenstein reads for me as pre-figuring the death of a weak, tired, and flawed God; Shelley, at least in my reading, pre-figures Nietzsche in writing of the death of God and offering a caustic critique of God's own moral failings.While I loved the themes of this novel and was moved by the plight of VFC, it is not a perfect novel. It seemed a bit over-stuffed at times, especially in describing Victor's early education and later travels throughout Europe and the British Isles. These sections caused the novel to drag a bit, but still, overall, I very much liked this novel and am glad to have finally read it. I really like that this is a novel with only one villain, Victor, and no hero other than an almost hero, VFC, who could have been great but, because of his undeniable sins, is a tragic figure. Therein lies the genius of Mary Shelley: she makes a child-murderer and a revenge killer who takes the lives of his nemesis's friends and family members a sympathetic, nearly heroic character.Final aside: why didn't Victor just make a wife for VFC? Come on, Victor! Why did you do all that work, and then abandon it? Also, why was making a female VFC so much harder than making VFC? You had already made VFC, so you knew how to create new life, yet to make a female VFC, you had to do intensive studies and travel to England for further research. I think it is obvious that Mary Shelley had a nice laugh at the patriarchy with this aspect of the story: woman's superiority makes it much, much more difficult to create a female than a male. I like this subtle yet actually not so subtle dig at the sexism that Mary Shelley had to endure in her time....more

title: The Chosen
author: Potok, Chaim
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Chosen is primarily a Bildungsroman focusing on the friendship of two boys--Reuven, a devout but somewhat liberal Orthodox Jew, and Danny, a brillThe Chosen is primarily a Bildungsroman focusing on the friendship of two boys--Reuven, a devout but somewhat liberal Orthodox Jew, and Danny, a brilliant Hasidic Jew--and the boys' respective relationships with their fathers. The novel offers insights into the history of Hasidic Judaism and the tensions between Hasidic Judaism and Orthodox Judaism. It gives the reader a window into how American Jews processed the tragedy of the Holocaust when the genocide first became widely known at the end of World War II, and it follows, through Reuven's father, post-war Zionist activism in the United States.A primary theme in The Chosen is the ability to see clearly. There are several concrete physical instantiations of this theme: early on, Reuven suffers an injury to his eye when he is hit by a softball, and it unclear whether his eye will heal and regain its sight. While in the hospital, Reuven meets a blind boy, Billy, who is hopeful of regaining his sight through an operation, and Danny, later in the novel, has to get eyeglasses to correct his impaired vision. But the more important aspect of this theme is the ability to see others clearly. Reuven has to learn to see how Danny has been shaped by his Hasidic upbringing and how much of Danny's identity is tied up in Hasidism. Reuven also has to overcome his inability to see what kind of man and father Reb Saunders, Danny's father, is because, for much of the novel, Reuven questions Reb Saunders's love for Danny and his strange way of parenting and interacting with Danny. Reb Saunders has to learn to see the world from Danny's perspective while Danny has to try to see a world beyond Hasidism. Serving as a lens to help all of them see and learn is Reuven's father.To those of us not who are outsiders to Judaism, the novel brings home the immense importance of sacred writings in Judaism. As someone who was raised in an evangelical Christian tradition, I have first-hand experience of how important study of the Bible is, but the evangelical love for and study of the Bible is nothing compared to Orthodox and Hasidic Jewish approaches to and reverence for the Torah and the Talmud: they memorize huge sections of their sacred writings; they study for literally hours a day; they write volumes and argue endlessly over interpretations of tiny portions of text. The Orthodox and Hasidic Jews portrayed in this novel are truly a people of the book, and they make Christian evangelicals and fundamentalists look like dilettantes when it comes to studying scripture.The final chapter of the novel is a revelation for both Danny and Reuven as well as Reb Saunders. All barriers are removed, and they all come to see one another clearly. Most readers, as did I, will shed some tears. The characters in this novel, because they come from a different religious tradition than do I, are in some ways quite alien to me, yet I found more similarities among us due to our mutual devotion to faith, family, and friendship. This is an exceptional novel because, among other reasons, it so beautifully universalizes the human experience....more

title: A Passage to India
author: Forster, E.M.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Part I: Mosque - 3.5 starsPart II: Caves - 5 starsPart III: Temple - 3 starscharacterization - 3.5 starsprose - 3.75 starsplot - 3.5 starsthematic devPart I: Mosque - 3.5 starsPart II: Caves - 5 starsPart III: Temple - 3 starscharacterization - 3.5 starsprose - 3.75 starsplot - 3.5 starsthematic development - 5 starspacing - 3 starsThis novel is a subdued study of colonialism, bigotry, bitterness, friendship, and forgiveness. Granted these themes, you may remark that it's strange for me to describe the novel as subdued, but it is all the same. The central plot point, (view spoiler)[Aziz, a Muslim Indian physician, is wrongfully accused of attempted rape by Adela Quested, a British woman, who later recants, thus freeing Aziz (hide spoiler)], would, in almost any other novel, erupt into a firestorm of racism, outrage, and violence, but A Passage to India steps softly and adeptly. It has all the potential to boil over with frothing injustice and jingoistic hatred but instead only simmers and then cools into a lukewarm soup, at first distasteful but, in the end, bland but edible. The novel is practical in its outlook and realistic in its outcome. There is an honesty in this novel that is rarely seen in literature.As you move through the novel, you expect fireworks. You do and do not want them. What you get, though, is a candle that flares up, dims almost to the point of being extinguished, and then settles in and quietly lights the room. This novel is wise about humans and their strange dispositions, their irrational prejudices, their fickle natures, and their capacity for both evil and good.I did not enjoy this novel. I appreciated it....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Friend is an extended reflection on death, suicide, grief, love, friendship, literature, and the art of writing. It is full of wit and wisdom and The Friend is an extended reflection on death, suicide, grief, love, friendship, literature, and the art of writing. It is full of wit and wisdom and is as much an existential meditation on life as a story. In fact, there is very little plot in this novella, and that is perfectly fine, for this is a work of ideas and emotion and metafiction told through the lens of an enduring friendship, a friendship that outlasts even death and that is, in a way, renewed in the bond between the narrator and her deceased friend's Great Dane, Apollo.I loved every word of this book. There was hardly a page where I did not learn something new or find myself highlighting the passage for its profundity or laughing at its good humor or marveling at its insight into the human condition. This is what great literature is all about.The Friend most deservedly won this year's (2018's) National Book Award for fiction. I was moved to tears of sorrow as I read it yet also experienced great joy and pleasure and most certainly learned from its wisdom. Thank you, Sigrid Nunez, for giving this book to the world! Bravo! Bravissimo!...more

title: So You Want to Talk About Race
author: Oluo, Ijeoma
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The strength of this book lies in Ijeoma Oluo's personal stories: she provides example after example of her firsthand experiences of dealing with raciThe strength of this book lies in Ijeoma Oluo's personal stories: she provides example after example of her firsthand experiences of dealing with racism; however, too many white people have no idea of the extent to which racism affects people of color on a day-to-day basis, and so by simply relating her own all-too-typical encounters with racism, Oluo brings home the reality of what it is like for a personal of color living in a society plagued with systemic racism.Beyond the personal stories, Oluo spells out the various aspects of racism and social injustice that people of color have to endure, and she proposes some solutions to these issues. While I agree with most everything that Oluo has to say, I did not find the writing, outside of her personal experiences, very engaging. It was dry and even dull--not the subject matter, but her prose.As I was reading this book, I could not help but think that, in the grand scheme of things, it's not going to have much of an impact. Most of the people who read this book will be people like me who are already in agreement with Oluo on the issues that the book addresses. The people who most need to read the book, those with explicit racist attitudes or who are unaware of and unconcerned with social justice, are not likely to read this book, and Oluo does not really do anything in the book to reach out to these people who most need to hear her message.While I did like this book and agree with Oluo's arguments, I just did not find it compelling or effective apart from her own personal stories. ...more

title: Nothing But the Truth
author: Avi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This story is aimed at high school or junior high school audience, and it shows. There is little to no character development: Philip, the antagonist, This story is aimed at high school or junior high school audience, and it shows. There is little to no character development: Philip, the antagonist, is identifiable only by his love of track and hatred of his ninth-grade English class; Philip's parents only distinguishing characteristic is their steadfast support for their son; the defining characteristic of Miss Narwin, the protagonist, is her profession as a teacher; the school administrators are little more than plot devices; Philip's fellow students are distinguishable only in terms of their sex and their names. There is no depth to any of these characters.The lack of character development, though it is certainly a weakness, is perhaps a bit understandable in this rather short and largely plot-driven novel. The plot is interesting enough to carry the reader forward effortlessly, but there is one rather gaping flaw: a key aspect of the story is a newspaper article that is full of half-truths based solely on Philip's rendition of his conflict with Miss Narwin. The school superintendent, after investigating this matter, writes up a clear, concise memo that addresses all the problems with Philip's version of the story and that completely exonerates Miss Narwin. If this memo had been sent to the reporter who wrote the original newspaper article or to any of the other reporters who follow up on the story, the negative publicity that school received from the initial article could have been immediately countered, but this is never done. The school superintendent, after drawing up this memo, decides, inexplicably, to try to make a scapegoat of Miss Narwin. Miss Narwin herself is strangely reluctant to defend herself: had she told any of the reporters who contacted the exact details of the story, the firestorm of bad publicity could have been ended promptly.Nothing But the Truth begins with an interesting premise, but it is a frustrating story in that none of the characters who could easily remedy the conundrum that arises do so. As such, it is simply not a very realistic story. I suppose that this story might work better for younger readers who may be more interested in plot than in characterization and who are less likely to notice or object to the gaping hole in the plot....more

title: Atonement
author: McEwan, Ian*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This novel is divided into 4 sections: Parts One, Two, and Three and then a final section that is basically an appendix. As I was finishing Part ThreeThis novel is divided into 4 sections: Parts One, Two, and Three and then a final section that is basically an appendix. As I was finishing Part Three and moving through the final section, I kept thinking how anticlimactic the novel was. The resolution was too pat, too easy, and most of Parts Two and Three seemed unnecessary diversions. But then came the penultimate page of the novel: it is a bombshell. It left me reeling. And it made me re-evaluate my opinion of the entire novel. Prior to that penultimate page, Atonement was a novel with a brilliant opening section (Part One) and great characterization of its protagonist, Briony, but the remainder of the novel was distinctly disappointing and too long, filled with material that seemingly added little value to the overall narrative--until everything is seen in light of that momentous revelation on the second-to-last page. My God! It left me breathless: (view spoiler)[Cecilia and Robbie, contrary to the formal ending in Part Three, had not reunited after Robbie returned from his World War II service in France, but, in fact, Robbie died of a battle wound, and Cecilia was killed by a German bomb that struck a London hospital where she was working as a nurse (hide spoiler)]. I was stunned and in tears as the novel came to an end. And it's not just some sentimental ending that got me (it's not sentimental at all); rather, the final revelation shifts the reader's perspective on everything that has come before, showing that Parts Two and Three weren't the literary filler that I had previously judged them to be but components whose vital relevance suddenly crystalized starkly.This is not a novel that I will soon, if ever, forget.Well done, Mr. McEwan! Bravo! Bravissimo!!!...more

title: Appointment in Samarra
author: O'Hara, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: There should be a term for the dramatic equivalent to a comedy of errors, where the mistakes and miscues pile one upon the other turning a situation tThere should be a term for the dramatic equivalent to a comedy of errors, where the mistakes and miscues pile one upon the other turning a situation that was initially merely an unpleasant difficulty into a tragedy. Tragedy, though, is not really an accurate term for Appointment in Samarra as, traditionally, tragedies presuppose gallant, heroic characters who fall from grace. Julian English is not such a character, but his fall is, nevertheless, sad.Julian is a character that, by all rights, we should not like. He comes from a well to do family (his father is a doctor), has a beautiful, intelligent wife, and has what, by all accounts, should be a great job as a Cadillac dealer, but he has gotten himself into trouble because of his own pettiness, stupidity, and selfishness, yet John O'Hara does such a great job of drawing this character that I could not help but hope that somehow Julian would be able to overcome his mistakes and that everything would turn out all right for him. I think this is a case where we are so much in the mind of Julian that we cannot help but identify with him. Although several other characters play prominent roles--Luther (Lute) Fliegler, who works for Julian; Irma Fliegler, Lute's wife; Al Grecco, a mob enforcer; Caroline English, Julian's wife; Ed Charney, a local mob boss and Al's employer--Julian is clearly the central character with the supporting characters, despite being very well drawn in their own right, functioning primarily as role-players in Julian's story. When we are with Julian, we feel slighted and offended when he is slighted and offended. We feel the pressures of his job and his marriage. And we also overlook the fact that he is, in many ways, a complete asshole: he treats his wife terribly; he is rude to his servants; he behaves like a prick: the incident in which he throws a drink in Harry Reilly's face, his blatant flirting with Helene in front of Caroline and their friends, the fight that he gets into with one-armed Froggy Ogden. Practically everything we see of Julian in this novel paints him in a bad light, yet O'Hara still humanizes him enough that we sympathize with him.The ending of this novel is not at all surprising granted Julian's short-tempered, self-pitying, self-centered nature and his desire for an easy solution to his very difficult marital (Caroline seems likely to leave him), financial (he is deeply in debt and his business prospects are dim), and social (his recent behavior has alienated him from many of his friends and the community at large) problems: (view spoiler)[he kills himself by carbon monoxide poisoning, which is an easy, painless method of suicide that totally fits with Julian's character (hide spoiler)]. I like the concise nature of O'Hara's story-telling. He could have easily expanded this novel from its 240 pages (in my version) to 400 or even 500 pages by focusing more on the broad cast of characters and their interesting backgrounds, yet he telescopes the plot very well to the elements most essential to Julian's story and brings the narrative to a quick but unhurried and powerful conclusion.This novel leads me to ponder whether Julian's fate can count as tragic given his nature. Can only the truly great be said to take tragic falls? Or can even those who have serious character flaws suffer tragedy? That is, is it a tragedy when one's terrible fate is not due to the whims of chance or circumstance but rather due to the very poor decisions that one makes, due even to one's very poor character? For me, I would have to say that the answer is, "no." Appointment in Samarra is not a tragedy because Julian is not a good person. His fate is the logical outcome of his character and behavior. Unlike many great tragic characters of literature, Julian gets what he deserves. What makes this short novel a great novel, though, is that, despite Julian being such a creep, we still care about him, almost even sympathize with him....more

review: The Library Book takes as its focus the fire that destroyed the downtown Los Angeles library in 1986. It is a story of true crime (or possibly no crimThe Library Book takes as its focus the fire that destroyed the downtown Los Angeles library in 1986. It is a story of true crime (or possibly no crime--that is part of the mystery), a history of the Los Angeles library in particular and all libraries in general, a social science survey of the role that libraries play in contemporary society, and a scientific investigation into structural fires and the evolution and development of arson investigations over the last century. In many ways, despite the tragic nature of its central element, it is a love song to libraries.I love libraries. The copy of The Library Book that I read was actually a library book. I am the target audience for this book, and it definitely struck home for me. If you are not terribly interested in libraries, though, this might not be the book for you, but even for readers largely uninterested in libraries, this book would still prove to be quite educational. ...more

Additionally, the ending is problematic: (view spoiler)[up until the last few sentences, we don't know what has happened to April other than that the Carls have most likely taken her with them somewhere, and then she suddenly just shows back up at Andy's apartment, and the novel ends. title: The Historian
author: Kostova, Elizabeth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Historian starts off so promisingly. The first 200 pages were entrancing, but the quality of the novel and my enjoyment of it ever so slowly decreThe Historian starts off so promisingly. The first 200 pages were entrancing, but the quality of the novel and my enjoyment of it ever so slowly decreased as the novel continued; unfortunately, there was a lot of novel left after the first 200 pages (676 pages total in my paperback version) so that by the end, I was not only relieved to have finally crossed the finish line but had also come to find reading The Historian a chore, finding only occasional passages engaging.The large middle section of the novel, which is composed primarily of a long letter (well over 400 pages of the novel) from the narrator's father to the narrator, forms the backbone of The Historian, but it is a backbone inflamed with osteoporosis. This epistolary section becomes excruciatingly repetitive to the point of being boring. The writing also grows excessively romantic, even maudlin. And when, at long last, we reach the climax, it is most disappointingly anti-climactic, wrapping up all too quickly and easily.A good editor could have turned this 676-page novel into a 350- to 400-page novel, and it would have been vastly improved even with the sentimental prose that grows ever more pervasive as the novel progresses.As it begins, The Historian holds so much promise to be a great horror novel, but it is gravely disappointing. Still, it is not terrible by any stretch. It is competent. It is slightly entertaining. Thus, it is a 2-star instead of a 1-star novel for me....more

title: Blindness
author: Saramago, José
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Edit: I had originally rated Blindness three stars, but after pondering it for another day, I'm down-grading it to two stars. So much that happens in Edit: I had originally rated Blindness three stars, but after pondering it for another day, I'm down-grading it to two stars. So much that happens in this novel is just unbelievable: (1) Why were the men of the "hoodlum" ward stealing money and valuables from the others in quarantine? What possible use could they have for money in their quarantine? And if they did regain their sight, then, of course, they would be prosecuted for theft. (2) Saramago tells us that one of the women, anticipating being gang-raped, is afraid that she might experience pleasure while being raped. Seriously. He says this. She is going to be gang-raped in the middle of a foul, malodorous, literal cesspool by disgusting men, and she is worried that it might be pleasurable. Are you kidding? It's just absolutely ridiculous, beyond stupid. (3) Why was the doctor's wife, the one person who was not blind, so reluctant to stand up for her husband and her friends while in quarantine? Why did it take her so long to act decisively to end their rape and torment? This is not how a real human being would act. -- And now that I have ranted about these bits of inanity (and there are many more that I could have mentioned), my original  is below, but I stand by revising this rating to two stars. Is Blindness trying to teach us something about humanity, or is it more of a reflection of humanity? I'd have to say it's the latter. The novel shows us that the worst circumstances can bring out the most atrocious and disgusting behavior in some humans while producing selfless, compassionate behavior in others. But this is nothing new. We all already know this. Blindness also shows us that we humans are very much a part of the animal kingdom: humans desperately seeking and fighting over food; humans defecating anywhere and everywhere with no shame; humans finding comfort in sex yet also committing rape gleefully and without remorse; humans stealing from and killing each other over food and sex; and humans finding almost their only comfort in sleep. The blindness of the novel reduces humanity to its most bestial impulses. The novel is a richly disgusting sensual palette, painting the stench of humanity--the odors of the body, bodily wastes, blood, vomit, decomposing bodies, rotting food--so vividly that some passages made me sick to my stomach. There is no question that Sarmago is a master of description. But is Saramago trying to tell us that, if civilization were to collapse, many of us would be little better than brutes? I don't think so, for this would be no great insight. We all already know this.So, are we meant to read this novel as an allegory that provides insight into the human condition? I don't think so. There is nothing in this novel that any thinking person does not already know. Instead, the novel to me is a reflection of humanity: it is the product of a writer who is all too aware of the horrors that humanity can commit and has committed but which also recognizes that we are not irredeemable: there is still good in humanity even when confronted with the worst that life has to offer. Again, this is not any deep revelation about humanity. It is a truism to anyone vaguely familiar with the history of our species.In the penultimate paragraph, the doctor's wife comments, "I don't think we did go blind, I think we are blind, Blind but seeing, Blind people who can see, but do not see" [sic]. What are we blind to? How good we have it in civilization? Surely, all of us realize how awful it would be to live in a Hobbesian state of nature outside civilization. What then? That we are animals? Again, this we know all too well. That we can behave in ghastly ways? But we know this, too. I found these lines trite and trying to be profound but profoundly failing. I suppose, to be charitable, that I could say that we are generally blind to the comforts of civilization, but this is because we rarely think about what life outside civilization would be like precisely because it is, for the most part, a very remote possibility. But it is not a blindness of ignorance or stupidity: we all readily recognize how terrible life would be for most of us were civilization to collapse.Blindness does not teach us any great lessons. It's a story with a fascinating premise. It has some great conflicts (particularly that between the "hoodlums" and the other wards during the quarantine at the mental hospital) and interesting pericopes as the core blind group, led by the doctor's wife, try to survive. But the characterization is weak, and this seems somewhat intentional as Saramago wants to focus on ideas rather than and even at the expense of characters, but because the ideas are really not all that novel or insightful, the lack of character development is a detriment to the novel as whole.Perhaps, however, I've missed the point. Maybe there is some grand metaphor here that I'm not seeing. I had thought that maybe this could be read as an epic work of pessimism or even nihilism: we are all just filthy animals who by pure chance have been raised above the level of beasts, but we are animals just the same with no greater meaning in life than to eat, sleep, reproduce, and die. But I don't think that is a legitimate interpretation of the text. If there is some marvelous meaning in this novel, then I am, ironically, blind to it.I have not read any of Saramago's other works, so I don't know if the prose style in this book is just his typical style or if he was trying to make his style reflect the atmosphere of the novel. If the latter is the case, he did succeed here. The long paragraphs (some of which run to 3 or more pages), the long sentences filled with comma splices, the dialogue written without attribution or quotation marks: this all contributes to a general haziness that at times makes it difficult to see what is going on in the novel: we readers become, to a degree, blind because of the prose style. I found myself both wearied by and appreciative of this style; however, overall, I found the style distracting and unnecessarily obsfuscatory.Blindness is a good story--a haunting story even--that will stick with me mainly for the grotesqueries it describes, but I have learned nothing from this novel. When I ponder Goethe's criteria for evaluating a work of art--(1) what is the creator trying to do? (2) did the creator accomplish it? (3) was it worth doing?--I find myself stumped by the first question: I'm not sure what Saramago is trying to do here, and if the first question is unanswered, then neither can the latter two be answered. Thus, artistically, Blindness is a failure. Blindness as a story qua story is actually an interesting read. Blindness as a story that attempts to communicate some greater message is uninteresting because that message (humans can be both really bad and really good in dire circumstances, or humans are kept from succumbing to their animal nature only by the tenuous and contingent power of civilization) is something that we all know. Because Blindness is a good story, I am giving it three stars even though as work of art, it fails....more

review: Amanda, the narrator of this novella, has been possessed by a demon named Naamah. It's certainly an intriguing premise, but it was not executed well. Amanda, the narrator of this novella, has been possessed by a demon named Naamah. It's certainly an intriguing premise, but it was not executed well. To get a good understanding of demonic possession, we would really need to know Amanda intimately so that we could see how the possession transforms her; however, Amanda's characterization is superficial, and that of Naamah is fairly stereotypical--exactly what we would expect from what we have read and seen of demons in popular culture.Another problem is that there is simply not much plot here. Basically, Amanda is possessed by a demon, and she starts to act progressively more strangely and more out of character. There is no real tension. Tellingly, for a novel that is supposed to be a horror story, Come Closer is never even remotely frightening.Come Closer is not terrible, but it is entirely forgettable. Luckily, it is very short, so reading it doesn't waste too much time....more

title: Boom Town: The Fantastical Saga of Oklahoma City, Its Chaotic Founding, Its Apocalyptic Weather, Its Purloined Basketball Team, and the Dream of Becoming a World-class Metropolis
author: Anderson, Sam
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Boom Town tells the story of my adopted home city, Oklahoma City, where I have lived for almost all my adult life. I love this city, and I love this bBoom Town tells the story of my adopted home city, Oklahoma City, where I have lived for almost all my adult life. I love this city, and I love this book. As such, my take on Boom Town is probably not as objective and unbiased as it could be; nevertheless, I think even those who have never been to Oklahoma City and have no real interest in Oklahoma City will still find it a great read.Sam Anderson chooses to tell his history of Oklahoma City through the lens of the city's beloved NBA team, the Thunder. But Boom Town is not just about the Thunder: Anderson begins with the overnight founding of the city in the Land Run of 1889, and he follows the city's fortunes from those early days to the present. Boom Town, however, is not a piece of public relations journalism for Oklahoma City: Anderson depicts the city not only at its best but at its worst: he covers the shameful racism, the rampant corporate greed, the grimy political machinations, and the ridiculous buffoonery and even criminality of some the city's most influential citizens. But he also shows the city at its finest, when it has pulled together to face the consequences of terrible tragedies: as I read Anderson's sections on the bombing of the Murrah Building and the devastating tornadoes of 1999 and 2013 (events of which I have vivid personal memories), I was moved to tears, and even as someone who lived through those events, I still learned a few new things from Anderson's history.Boom Town is a fun, funny, fascinating, heart-breaking, somber, sometimes maddening, and, in the end, inspiring biography of Oklahoma City. Even if you know nothing about Oklahoma City and couldn't even locate it on a map, I think you'll enjoy this book. One caveat: much of this book (probably about a third) is devoted to the Oklahoma City Thunder, so if you're not a basketball fan, these sections might not quite hold your interest, but even I am only a casual fan, and I still found the Thunder sections very engaging. But if you are a basketball fan (especially if you are a Thunder fan), you really need to read this book.Sam Anderson is not a native of Oklahoma City, but in the process of writing this book, as he himself admits, he came to feel like an Oklahoman. I think he fell in love with this city. But as in any truly loving relationship, Anderson still sees the flaws in his beloved, and his book is honest about the city's shortcomings. I loved this book almost as much as I love Oklahoma City, and part of the joy of reading this book, for me, was being able to get an outsider's view--certainly a much more objective view than my own--of my adopted home city. Bravo, Mr. Anderson. Bravo!...more

title: Severance
author: Ma, Ling*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Severance is a slow-burning amalgamation of a several genres: it is an immigrant's story, a romance, a tale of the vicissitudes of urban professional Severance is a slow-burning amalgamation of a several genres: it is an immigrant's story, a romance, a tale of the vicissitudes of urban professional life, and an apocalyptic adventure set in a world ravaged by a pandemic. It will likely remind many readers of Emily St. John Mandel's Station Eleven and Cormac McCarthy's The Road, but while these three novels do share some similar elements, Severance is its own unique tale.In Severance, civilization as we know it is coming to an end, but that's only a small part of the story. Largely, this novel is the story of our narrator, Candace Chen: her childhood, her life as a 20-something working for a large publishing company in New York, her relationships with her family and with her boyfriend, and her adventures and misadventures when a plague kills most of humanity. It's a tale suffused with sadness, regret, and melancholy but also always ever tinged with hope.And there is also suspense and danger and even zombies--though not so named and not the typical kind but still zombies in a peculiar way. The story grows more and more engrossing, and I sped through the final 100-odd pages hardly able to turn the pages quickly enough. I had no expectation of how the story would end because I've never read a novel quite like this, and the ending, like the novel as a whole, was practically perfect....more

title: We Were the Mulvaneys
author: Oates, Joyce Carol
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5. starsThis novel is an extended character study of five of the six members of the Mulvaney family: a mother, a father, and four children. The sixt3.5. starsThis novel is an extended character study of five of the six members of the Mulvaney family: a mother, a father, and four children. The sixth family member, the youngest son, Judd, is the novel's narrator, and while he plays a role in the story, his role is relatively minor compared to that of his parents, his sister, and his two brothers, and so we don't get to know Judd, who focuses only very little upon himself, as well as we do his siblings and his parents. The rape of Marianne, the daughter and sister in the family, when she is sixteen is the pivot point around which this story rotates. As one might expect, nothing is ever the same for Marianne after she has been raped, and her rape has deep, far-reaching consequences for her entire family and the home in which she grew up.We Were the Mulvaneys paints the lives of the Mulvaneys in brilliant, realistic colors. But it is a very slow story, and it is slow precisely because there is not a crisis that has to be resolved: the novel is simply the story of the lives of these family members and how they were all affected by Marianne's rape. Many readers may feel bogged down in the middle to late sections of the novel and may find it drags on for too long, but few will fail to appreciate Joyce Carol Oates's genius in constructing a thoughtful, intricate mythos of an entire family....more

author: O'Conner, Patricia T.

review: This is a good book for word nerds and people who love grammar, etymologies, and the idiosyncrasies of the English language. It is written from a descThis is a good book for word nerds and people who love grammar, etymologies, and the idiosyncrasies of the English language. It is written from a descriptivist perspective, so grammar fascists and linguistic pedants will probably hate this book: it doesn't label various usages as proper or improper but simply looks at how English speakers actually have used in the past and continue to use the language. Prescriptivists, then, will not find this book to their liking, but for almost anyone else interested in how the English language and specific words and usages have evolved and developed over the past thousand or so years, this is a very entertaining and educational book....more

The characterization, writing, and pacing are well done. I have rated this story as 4 stars instead of 5 because the author makes an odd, dissonant choice with the narrative voice in the last section and because (view spoiler)[we are ultimately given no answers: we don't know who or what--God or some malevolent force or mental illness or something else or maybe even nothing--has inspired the four antagonists (Leonard, Sabrina, Adriane, and Redmond) to attack the protagonists, a family of three (Wen, Eric, and Andrew). We don't know if the world really is ending. We don't know what ultimately happens to Eric and Andrew. We get no explanation at all; this is not always necessary to all stories, but in this novel, the failure to answer these questions is deeply unsatisfying--although one could read this lack of an explanation as a metaphor for the existential condition of humanity in general, and I think that this is a legitimate reading that does mitigate the general dissatisfaction with the abrupt ending that leaves us wondering what has happened. Despite my problems with the ending, I was still able to appreciate the novel as whole, but many readers will very much not like the ending, and that will likely result in an overall negative experience with this novel (hide spoiler)]....more

review: I've read several fairy tale re-tellings or re-imaginings, but Naomi Novik's Spinning Silver is easily among the best. Spinning Silver takes only the I've read several fairy tale re-tellings or re-imaginings, but Naomi Novik's Spinning Silver is easily among the best. Spinning Silver takes only the basic idea from Rumplestiltskin (transforming one material, straw in the original fairy tale and silver in Novik's tale, into gold) and spins out a tale that is otherwise original. Novik's tale has everything you could want in a fairy tale--strange magic, a clever and resourceful heroine, a brave princess, evil nobles, noble peasants, a fairy king who rules a land of winter, a vile monster, and even a bit of romance--with a plot that keeps surprising you and great characterization. Spinning Silver is a novel-length fairy tale that is both a perfectly told fairy tale and a well-written novel....more

title: Dune        (Dune, #1)
author: Herbert, Frank
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Upon learning that one of my favorite directors, Denis Villeneuve, is adapting Dune for the screen, I decided that I should finally get around to readUpon learning that one of my favorite directors, Denis Villeneuve, is adapting Dune for the screen, I decided that I should finally get around to reading the novel, which is much lauded in the science fiction community where it has a reputation as one of the best, if not the best, science fiction novels ever written. While I found Dune to be a very well written novel that entertained me from beginning to end, it did not quite live up to the hype for me: I would not rank it among the top tier of science fiction novels that I have read--though it is far better than average.Dune for me reads more as fantasy than science fiction. It is filled with the magic and mysticism of the Bene Gesserit, the fanaticism and superstition of the Fremen, and the occult soothsaying abilities of Paul (Muad'Dib). Like other fantasy novels, it is a novel of palace intrigue, power struggles, adventures in an exotic land, and war. Apart from space travel, which plays only a tertiary role in Dune, and the Fremen efforts to terraform Arrakis from an extreme desert into a less arid planet, science takes a distant back seat to the fantasy elements and the conflict between Paul and his Fremen supporters and their enemies, the Hakonnens. So while Dune is not among the best science fiction novels that I have read, I have few qualms about placing it among the best fantasy novels.Still, however one might classify Dune, it is a fantastically entertaining read with some very well developed characters and marvelous world-building. I did feel that the novel ended rather abruptly and a bit too easily: Paul's victories--his military conquest of the Harkonnens and his political out-maneuvering of the Padishah emperor by forcing the emperor to give his daughter in marriage to Paul--come about rather hastily with Baron Harkonnen's and the emeperor's forces providing too little resistance based upon their strength and formidability as portrayed earlier in the novel. And so Dune ends with Paul in ascendancy and moving to consolidate his power but with a very uncertain future. Of course, there are sequels to Dune, so I realize that the story does continue and likely provides more narrative closure in those sequels, but this original novel as a self-contained whole did not quite satisfy me. My  may seem overly critical, but that is not reflective of my general experience with this novel. I very much enjoyed reading Dune. The characters are wonderful; the plot is beautifully developed; the world-building is extraordinary; the intrigue and betrayals and adventures in the desert landscape are thoroughly engaging; all of these factors come together in a novel that kept me eagerly turning the pages the entire way through; I was never once even remotely bored. And now that I have finished Dune, I cannot wait to see how this world looks through the lens of Denis Villeneuve's cinematic imagination....more

The two primary characters, the narrator and her best friend, are sculpted exquisitely; they are vivid works of art.The narrative conceit is intriguing; its execution is well imagined, thoughtful, witty, and, at times, quite funny.The only drawback is that this novel (or, at 290 pages, perhaps novella is a better description) does become repetitive, with the same structural elements being somewhat overused. Still, the writing is so good that I very much enjoyed My Year of Rest and Relaxation.My Year of Rest and Relaxation will be off-putting to some readers. It's odd. At times, it's gross. It can be rather unpleasant. Depression, mental illness, death, and dealing with these are dominant themes. These elements are definitely in my wheelhouse, so I really liked this book, but if this sounds too dark to you, it might not be your cup of tea. title: The Order of Time
author: Rovelli, Carlo
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a relatively short explication of the nature of time from Carlo Rovelli, a physicist who specializes in loop quantum gravity. Rovelli has a teThis is a relatively short explication of the nature of time from Carlo Rovelli, a physicist who specializes in loop quantum gravity. Rovelli has a tendency to wax poetic and existential, so while the focus of this book is a scientific examination of time, there is also a great deal of personal reflection.Rovelli deconstructs some of the more popular scientific and philosophical views of time and then provides his own view, the details of which are complex and which I won't summarize here as anyone interested should simply read this relatively short book. Having read fairly widely on the physics of time, I can say that Rovelli's view is novel and attractive: to this layperson, it makes sense, which is not always the case in the strange worlds of relativity and quantum physics, and is grounded scientifically, drawn from a cutting edge field of contemporary physics, loop quantum gravity. Rovelli's approach to time makes a valiant effort at resolving the paradoxes that arise in both presentism and eternalism while also providing a fascinating answer to the question of why the universe seems to have been in a low entropy state in its earliest history.For those who are curious about one of the most baffling of metaphysical mysteries, the nature of time, I highly recommend this book....more
