title: We Need to Talk About Kevin
author: Shriver, Lionel*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Mere minutes ago, I finished reading We Need to Talk About Kevin, and I am now in desperate need of an intellectual and spiritual palate cleanser. TheMere minutes ago, I finished reading We Need to Talk About Kevin, and I am now in desperate need of an intellectual and spiritual palate cleanser. The bleak, gray intellectual nihilism with which this novel begins morphs, by the end of the novel, into the soul-crushing, grievous, cold, black moral and existential nihilism of an unrelenting, unforgiving void. I want to go watch a bunch of upbeat re-runs of Frasier or The Mindy Project. I want to watch some heart-warming or humorous Christmas movies. I long for the comfort, long since departed, that my innocent and hopeful religious faith provided me from early childhood through early adulthood. We Need to Talk About Kevin has left me in an existential stupor, the likes of which no novel has ever before induced.Reading We Need to Talk About Kevin has been a strange experience. At first, I was fascinated by the contentious, hostile relationship between Eva and Kevin. I was psychoanalyzing Kevin throughout and marveling at how, despite the persistent antagonism between him and his mother, Kevin was every bit Eva's son and barely that of his doting father, Franklin. Everything that Eva hated and feared in Kevin could be traced right back to Eva: Kevin's disdain, his arrogance, his cold-heartedness, his quiet, seething anger--all of this we could see, to a degree, in Eva. This is not to say that everything about Kevin had come from Eva: his sociopathic amorality is an anomaly, and that's what makes this novel truly terrifying: in the final analysis, Kevin's evil is ultimately inexplicable. We want a universe that we can understand. We want the ills and evils of this world to somehow make some sort of sense: it was a crime of passion; it was drugs; it was a mental disorder; it was parental abuse; it was due to abject poverty; it was God working in mysterious but ultimately justifiable ways; etc. What we don't want is to dig into the mind of the killer, into the heart of darkness, and find, at bottom, an evil that is not a mere Platonic absence of the Good but rather an impersonal, demoniac force that eats away at hope and light and joy.We Need to Talk About Kevin is so many things. It is a profound and disturbing meditation on parenthood, especially motherhood, and the idols and idylls that society creates around the parent-child relationship. It is a brilliant excoriation of a modern culture that revels in titillation and that is all too eager for consumption of stories of the deepest darkness of which humanity is capable, and, ironically, this very novel itself plays to our fascination with this very type of evil.We Need to Talk About Kevin begins by painting a picture of an indifferent nihilism: a detached amorality that rises above society, that laughs at the slave-morality that Nietzsche skewered. But Shriver shows how this intellectual nihilism oozes into all aspects of life and corrupts everything, ending in mass murder and patricide and sororicide.****SPOILERS AHEAD********SPOILERS AHEAD********SPOILERS AHEAD********SPOILERS AHEAD********SPOILERS AHEAD****What struck me the most about this novel was how harshly the murders of Franklin and Celia affected me. Although I suspected early on that Franklin and, when we finally met her, Celia, might be dead, I was never really certain until Eva discovered their bodies. From the very beginning, we know that Kevin has murdered a handful of classmates, a teacher, and a cafeteria worker, and while these murders are terrible, there is a level of detachment to these murders: one, we don't really know any of these murder victims; and, two, Kevin doesn't have a close relationship with any of them. However, we have seen how Franklin dotes on Kevin and how Celia worships her big brother. Although he has been cruel and heedless of everyone's feelings throughout, I still had hoped that somehow, there was a family bond between him and his father and sister. Thus, their murders left me distraught.While the novel takes us into to the bowels of hell, it does, at long last, give us some small modicum of hope: Kevin's refusal to speak ill of Eva in the interview he gives to the documentary filmmaker; his displaying Eva's picture on his cell wall; his gift to Eva of Celia's prosthetic eye; and finally and most moving, the last exchange he has with Eva in which he lamentably answers her question of why by honestly saying that he doesn't know. Kevin, at long last, seems to be remorseful. Maybe he is not utterly lost. And if he is not lost, then there is still hope for Eva, for all she has left in the world is Kevin.We Need to Talk About Kevin is a remarkable work. It is the best literary portrayal of sociopathy that I have ever encountered as well as being a fascinating exploration of family dynamics. It is also interesting as a pointedly secular, areligious (but not anti-religious) novel. It shows a godless, nihilistic world, and although it does not give us any grand redemption or dramatic spiritual conversions, it does, in the final meeting between Kevin and Eva, show us that the world is not totally devoid of hope....more

When I finished reading Bearskin and marveling at the gorgeous writing, I asked myself, "Is there anything in this story that stands out? In a year's time, will I be able to recall anything beyond a vague outline of the plot?" Because I had to answer this question in the negative, I can't really rate this novel more than three stars. Yes, this novel was an entertaining read that was extremely well written, but, ultimately, it's standard fare for this genre.Based on the talent that the author has demonstrated here, I would say that he has the potential to write an exceptional novel, and so I will be interested to see what he writes next. review: Delightful. Is it appropriate to call a murder mystery delightful? Perhaps not. Nevertheless, The Word Is Murder is engrossing. It's witty, twisty, anDelightful. Is it appropriate to call a murder mystery delightful? Perhaps not. Nevertheless, The Word Is Murder is engrossing. It's witty, twisty, and twisted. I thoroughly enjoyed it.The Word Is Murder is one of those mysteries where all the clues are carefully dispersed, but, unless you're Sherlock Holmes, you won't solve the puzzle yourself. You'll find yourself rather surprised by the solution while appreciating the author's subtlety and creativity.Besides the mystery, there is also the brilliant literary device adopted in the novel: the author, Anthony Horowitz, writes this novel in the first-person and reports on events that, he claims, actually happened. Never once, not even in the acknowledgements, does he give up the game. This novel is written not as a novel but as a work of true crime. But, of course, it is fiction. Or is it?After the great success of last year's Magpie Murders, The Word Is Murder firmly establishes Anthony Horowitz among the leading lights of mystery novelists. Well done, Mr. Horowitz!...more

title: Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde
author: Stevenson, Robert Louis
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The basic conceit of this story is absurd: Dr. Jekyll believes that we all have two natures warring inside of us, one evil and the other good. He descThe basic conceit of this story is absurd: Dr. Jekyll believes that we all have two natures warring inside of us, one evil and the other good. He describes these two natures as "polar twins . . . continuously struggling," and he believes that if these twins "could be housed in separate identities, life would be relieved of all that was unbearable; the unjust might go his way . . . and the just could walk steadfastly and securely on his upward path . . . "Now, of course, it's not absurd to believe that we all do struggle with conflicting desires, but to believe that we have two separate natures completely opposed is not reflective of how I feel nor, I venture to say, how most people feel. But even if we all felt ourselves torn between good and evil natures struggling within us, I don't think any of us find our moral struggles unbearable. For most of us, we are easily able to make the right choices and don't find making and doing the right thing to be remotely unbearable.Moreover, the idea of splitting ourselves from a complex, morally ambiguous, singular identity into two separate, unambiguous, moral identities does not seem a good solution to the problem of our internal struggles with our conscience: in creating two new identities, we destroy our previous identity. Dr. Jekyll's solution is a form of psychological suicide: the original Dr. Jekyll, with his conflicted conscience, is destroyed in order to produce two new identities: the purified Dr. Jekyll and the evil Mr. Hyde, neither of whom is the same person as the original Dr. Jekyll. Dr. Jekyll, rather than solving the problem of his conflicted conscience, simply evades the problem entirely by creating, through his potion-making, two entirely new identities. And since these two new identities still inhabit the same body, there is still the struggle between these two identities as to which will ultimately control the body, so there is still a rather difficult conflict even with the "solution" at which Dr. Jekyll arrives.Because the psychological conceit of and solution to this story are utterly ridiculous, I found the story itself equally ridiculous. Still, the writing is good, and I was entertained and caught up in the story of the murder of Carew, and I did appreciate the way the story ended with Mr. Hyde committing suicide (which seemed a logical outcome granted the arc of the narrative), thus bringing an end to all three identities (the original Dr. Jekyll, the purified Dr. Jekyll, and Mr. Hyde) for good. As a result, I didn't hate this story, but I didn't really like it either, so I have rated it two stars....more

title: The Hunger
author: Katsu, Alma*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Hunger is without doubt one of the best works of horror fiction I've read in the last decade, and I daresay it's among the best I've ever read. ItThe Hunger is without doubt one of the best works of horror fiction I've read in the last decade, and I daresay it's among the best I've ever read. It's also a beautifully structured work of historical fiction, but it's historical fiction with a chilling supernatural twist.Unlike much horror fiction, The Hunger excels at characterization. It doesn't give us cardboard cut-out characters put forth just to be slaughtered or to serve as simplistic villains and heroes; instead, our author, Alma Katsu, gives us layered, complex characters, most of whom are morally ambiguous with a realistic mix of traits such that we go from being disgusted by a character's vice in one chapter to being delighted by her or his virtue in another. Katsu's artistic genius shines in her development of the setting. The landscape of the wagon trail from Missouri to California becomes a character in its own right--from the hot, harsh, parched plains in summer to the brutally frigid, unforgiving snows of the mountains in winter. Nature oppresses and harasses the members of the wagon train to the point of becoming a villain in its own right. This novel submerses the reader in sensory experience: parched throats, starving stomachs, bloodied and gaping gashes, bone-crushing wounds, blackly frostbitten fingers, eerie and unsettling screams and howls, stinking corpses, and reeking human bodies in cramped and crowded tents. You feel, taste, smell, see, and hear all the evil of the unforgiving environment, the human characters, and the animal and supernatural elements. By so pointedly and realistically depicting the sensory world, Katsu places the reader inescapably in the midst of the horror.The Hunger maintains an atmosphere of unease and unsettledness from beginning to end. This is not a novel that relies on jump scares or horrifying encounters (though there are certainly some of these elements in the novel); Katsu creates a realm permeated by a mysterious terror that haunts the reader throughout and never lets up. Finally, The Hunger ends perfectly: (view spoiler)[there is enough redemption in the survival of James Reed and his discovery and rescue of his step-daughter, Virginia Reed, at Truckee Lake, to allow the story to end, despite all of its horrors, on a hopeful note. (hide spoiler)]I absolutely loved The Hunger. It is one of the best new novels--if not the best--that I have read in 2018....more

title: The Perfect Mother
author: Molloy, Aimee
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 3.5 starsThe Perfect Mother is another in a long line of psychological thrillers focused on women in dire straits--novels like The Girl on the Train, 3.5 starsThe Perfect Mother is another in a long line of psychological thrillers focused on women in dire straits--novels like The Girl on the Train, In a Dark, Dark Wood, The Woman in the Window, and Behind Her Eyes. The Perfect Mother is slightly above the cut for this genre, but all in all, it's fairly typical--definitely entertaining but still lacking anything to really distinguish it from other novels in this genre.What I most enjoyed about this novel was the surprise it delivers. It's not really a twist ending; rather, the novel plays on a fairly fundamental assumption that most readers--myself included--will make, and then it reveals that that assumption, while rational and understandable, was completely wrong.I also enjoyed how the author was able to create perhaps the most annoying character I've encountered in quite some time: Francie. Francie is one of the four main characters (the others being Nell, Colette, and Winnie), and all three other main characters as well as Francie's husband find their patience extraordinarily tried by Francie. And Francie definitely drove me bananas as well, but I liked the arc her story took in this novel. It takes a good writer to create such an unlikable character and yet keep that character from being hated by the readers. We don't hate Francie; we just get sick to death of her.Besides not being terribly original, my main problem with The Perfect Mother is the number of red herrings. The red herrings are problematic not because they are red herrings but because they are so obviously red herrings. The story follows numerous tangents down paths that any reader can see are dead ends, and so these red herrings ultimately serve more as filler instead of adding anything of much substance to the story.The Perfect Mother is a quick, easy, and fun read but falls into that category of novels that you enjoy while you're reading but that you largely forget shortly after you finish....more

title: Foucault's Pendulum
author: Eco, Umberto
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Having loved Umberto Eco's earlier novel, The Name of the Rose, I had high hopes for Foucault's Pendulum. Those hopes were dashed. Foucault's PendulumHaving loved Umberto Eco's earlier novel, The Name of the Rose, I had high hopes for Foucault's Pendulum. Those hopes were dashed. Foucault's Pendulum begins promisingly enough, with the narrator, Casaubon, hiding out in a Paris museum and giving us the back story as to how he finds himself there, and over the first 100 or so pages (of 641 pages), he spins an interesting tale about how his work for a publishing company in Milan has brought him into contact with a number of conspiracy theorists and their works. For those first 100 pages, I was hooked.And then come the final 500-odd pages. These are the pages that try men's and women's souls. The novel becomes a labyrinthine morass of conspiracy theories, tales of from Belbo's childhood during World War II, Casaubon's recollections of his time in Brazil learning about secret societies and attending occult rituals, and various interludes relating to both Belbo's and Casaubon's romantic lives--all told in such a manner as to bore the average reader to tears. But it's not merely boring. It's worse; it's so bad that it's painful. Rarely have I wanted to throw a book across the room, but I felt that urge on many occasions with Foucault's Pendulum. The examination of conspiracy theories that forms the main body of Foucault's Pendulum is both exhausting and trivial; these chaotic ramblings would try the patience even of the most ardent believer in secret societies and mysterious powers that seek to control the world: pages and pages and still more pages discussing the inane ideas and spurious connections posited by innumerable medieval and modern writers about the Templars, the Rosicrucians, the Masons, the Illuminati, the Golden Dawn, and the Assassins. So many times, I wanted to quit, but I pressed on, believing that surely a good end would justify the means of getting to said end through this insipid madness, this horrendous word salad of a middle section. But I was disappointed: the ending is terrible. Although the build-up to the climax that begins about 100 pages before the novel's end is actually pretty good, the climax itself is anticlimactic and unimaginative. I was left cold and frustrated. I cannot help but wonder if Eco intended this massive tome as a farce, as a joke on the reader. Eco is undoubtedly a brilliant writer, and we see flashes of his genius throughout Foucault's Pendulum, but brilliant writers still can and do write tripe. This is tripe. Now, I understand that one can find a larger existential message about the absurdity and ridiculousness of existence in this novel, but I don't need 641 pages of mind-numbing minutiae about the Templars and the Rosicrucians and secret histories to get this message. I hated Foucault's Pendulum. The best part about reading this novel was finishing it and realizing I don't have to return to this stupid, boring world of occult nonsense. ...more

If you can't afford to buy it, don't bother going to your library: they will have copies (likely many, many copies), but they will all be loaned out, so you will have to put a hold on it and wait for a few weeks before it comes available. Get on that reserve list now!Educated: A Memoir is a truly amazing story. It is for very good reason that it has been on the New York Times nonfiction bestseller list since it was published in February of this year (2018).No  of Educated will do it justice. It is stunning. It is nonfiction with a story that rivals any work of fiction in terms of drama, heart, intensity, and uniqueness. The more you read of this memoir, the more drawn into its heartbreakingly strange, even frightening world you become. While Educated is nothing like a thriller or a mystery, I nonetheless found myself utterly entranced, consuming the pages voraciously and reading as quickly as I could to find out what would happen next, hardly able to set this book aside for any reason. Educated is a story unlike any I have ever read, taking me on a journey to a completely alien world: the world of a little girl growing into a woman in a family of fundamentalist Mormons living in rural Idaho and preparing for the end of the world. This little girl, the author Tara Westover, has a personal story that is tragic yet, happily, also hopeful. Her memoir tells the story of growing up in an exotic (to most of us) family of homeschooling, apocalyptic, survivalist Mormons and growing out of that family as she, through the painful but liberating process of gaining an education that the world outside her circle would see as fairly typical, comes to a new understanding of the world beyond the extremely limited perspective of her family.The most compelling, moving, and terrifying aspect of Educated is Westover's evolving relationship with her family. I don't want to spoil anything, but I will say that the psychological, spiritual, and even physical abuse that she endures at the hands of her own family members left me stunned and gasping. Westover's story makes me extremely grateful for the family that I have, for the way that we all, despite our differences, still very much love and care for each other. This memoir makes me weep for those families, like Westover's, where deep divisions form, where parents separate themselves from children, where siblings cease to talk to one another, where love is replaced with bitterness, anger, and unforgiveness. Educated will will leave you in shock, will make you weep, will make you think, and will educate you. It is an unforgettable story. It is unquestionably one of the best works of nonfiction I have ever read. I cannot recommend this book highly enough....more

title: The Elizas
author: Shepard, Sara*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As psychological thrillers go, The Elizas is a cut above the rest. This isn't the best novel I've read in 2018, but it is certainly among the most enjAs psychological thrillers go, The Elizas is a cut above the rest. This isn't the best novel I've read in 2018, but it is certainly among the most enjoyable--if not the most enjoyable. The deeper into this novel I progressed, the more engrossed I became and the more difficult I found it to set this novel aside to do necessary things like sleep and work.Too many of the novels in this genre play with the same basic premise--a woman in distress who may or may not be reliable and who suffers from some sort of emotional or psychological issue and who has credibility problems--but don't really do anything much with said premise. The Elizas puts that premise to great use: there is a legitimately bizarre and seemingly inexplicable mystery at the heart of this novel, and it's extremely enjoyable to watch the protagonist struggle to sort out this maddening, frustrating puzzle. There isn't really a big twist like so many of these novels have, but there is a methodical, meticulous unraveling of the central mystery that is utterly delightful and satisfying.The Elizas is not merely a good beach read; it's a good couch read, a good bed read, a good sitting-at-your-desk-at-work read; it's a good read anywhere. And it's not just good. It's great!...more

title: A Man Called Ove
author: Backman, Fredrik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: 2.5 stars (rounded up to 3 stars)Apologies to my sister-in-law, Lauren, who loved this novel, but I didn't love it.Now, I did love the first 50 to 60 2.5 stars (rounded up to 3 stars)Apologies to my sister-in-law, Lauren, who loved this novel, but I didn't love it.Now, I did love the first 50 to 60 pages of A Man Called Ove: the story is light, airy, funny, and cheerful and seasoned with a dash of Ove's grumpiness. I found myself literally laughing out loud on almost every one of those early pages. After those opening 50 to 60 pages, though, the novel stalls. The characters that I initially found so enchanting do not grow nor show any real depth: they are all caricatures more than characters. By the end of the novel, no one has really changed; all that's different is the circumstances of their lives. Ove is still the grumpy old man that he has always been--even as a young man. The novel tries to show Ove transforming as he interacts with Parvaneh and her family and his other neighbors, but he doesn't really change at all because, although Ove has always been cranky and cantankerous, he has also always been, at heart, a decent, loving person with a great deal of integrity. As the novel opens, we have a cast of characters all of whom are fundamentally good and loving, and as the novel progresses these characters all find new friends to bring within their circle of love. This is not a bad thing at all, but there is no real drama in this novel.Instead, A Man Called Ove is a series of events in the life of Ove. In each of these vignettes, Ove reacts just as we would expect him to from the initial portrait that the novel paints of him. We get the same type of jokes and humor over and over. The novel feels hackneyed and even a bit boring by the end. All of the characters are stereotypes, and we can easily predict how they will act because they always act stereotypically.My negative comments notwithstanding, this isn't a terrible novel. The characters are likable. There are many passages that are delightfully humorous. There is some drama--though the outcome is never really in question. I did find the ending moving in spite of its being quite clichéd. It is a very easy and quick read. But, overall, it is a mediocre novel and thus deserves a rating, 2.5 stars out of 5, reflective of that mediocrity. ...more

title: Prairie Fires: The American Dreams of Laura Ingalls Wilder
author: Fraser, Caroline
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As a child, I loved both the Little House books and television show, so it was with great anticipation that I picked up Caroline Fraser's biography ofAs a child, I loved both the Little House books and television show, so it was with great anticipation that I picked up Caroline Fraser's biography of Laura Ingalls Wilder, Prairie Fires. As is usually the case with our idols, the reality falls far short of the myth.The Ingalls family that I grew up loving--especially the patriarch, Charles Ingalls, and author, Laura Ingalls Wilder--were not the largely jovial, struggling yet always eventually successful farm family that the books portray. In fact, while the books are, for the most part, based on historical incidents from the lives of the Ingalls family, they are highly stylized and in many instances fictionalized. This is demonstrated through Fraser's meticulous research, drawing extensively on the correspondence between Laura and her daughter, Rose Wilder Lane.This biography is almost as much a biography of Rose as it is of Laura, for it was Rose who was primarily responsible for her mother's writing career, and Rose edited and, to a small degree, even re-shaped much of the material in her mother's novels--and this biography shows that these books are better classified as novels than as non-fiction. Rose was a well-established writer (something of a yellow journalist) long before her mother even began crafting her novels. It's fairly safe to say that, without Rose, Laura never would have written these novels.Prairie Fires places the lives of the Ingalls family within the historical and cultural context and gives a much more realistic view of life on the prairie than do Laura's novels. As a good biography, it also paints an intimate portrait of Laura and Rose. Sadly (to me), Laura was not an altogether likable person--moody, insolent, prickly, often distant even from her loved ones (even missing her mother's funeral), and constantly fighting with the daughter that she nevertheless loved very much. Still, Laura was ultimately a sympathetic person, but Rose decidedly was not. Rose was fickle, selfish, frequently dishonest, vindictive, and extremely reactionary in terms of her politics. Save for her devotion to her parents, which though it wavered never ultimately failed, Rose had very very little to recommend herself.Prairie Fires is the real story of the Little House world. It's a rather dismal revelation of the harsh nature of life on the prairie in the middle to late nineteenth century, but it is not completely dark, for it does depict the love and even happiness that could still be found in the lives of the pioneers. In the end, this biography shows that the Little House novels and much more so the television show partake far more of myth than reality....more

title: Everything Happens for a Reason: And Other Lies I've Loved
author: Bowler, Kate
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: From several summaries that I read, I had anticipated that this book would be a philosophical and theological reflection on death as the author faced From several summaries that I read, I had anticipated that this book would be a philosophical and theological reflection on death as the author faced a devastating cancer diagnosis. However, there is very little serious discussion of the problem of pain and suffering. Instead, this book is a memoir. It details the author's personal struggles and victories as she deals with both her cancer and how people--family, friends, colleagues, and complete strangers who read an article about her experiences in the New York Times--engage with her in light of her illness.What this book does very well is provide a great lesson in how to approach and engage with those who have been diagnosed with a terminal illness. Where it doesn't succeed (because it doesn't even really try) is in providing a first-hand existential reflection on death and human finitude from someone faced with the very real prospect of dying all too soon and all too young. If you’re looking for a profound, intellectual discussion on death and mortality, you’ll not find it here....more

title: Tangerine
author: Mangan, Christine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wait. Wait.Keep waiting.Wait. Wait.Be patient for just a bit longer.You won't be disappointed. This novel delivers!Tangerine is a prime example of a sWait. Wait.Keep waiting.Wait. Wait.Be patient for just a bit longer.You won't be disappointed. This novel delivers!Tangerine is a prime example of a slow burn. The first 200-or-so pages (of 308 pages) take their time. There is no rush. And these early pages are certainly good--building character and setting the stage. But the last 100 pages really pay off.The book market is flooded with psychological thrillers, most of which are entirely forgettable. Tangerine, though, is an exception. A dark mystery in the past, peril in the present, and a future that we readers can't wait to see but have no idea how we'll get there or where the novel will finally take us--this is one of those rare thrillers that is, indeed, thrilling.The cover blurb from Joyce Carol Oates reads, "As if Donna Tartt, Gillian Flynn, and Patricia Highsmith had collaborated on a screenplay to be filmed by Hitchcock." I absolutely adore all three of these authors. Now, I'm not quite willing to say that Christine Mangan has reached their level in this debut novel, but she is close.(view spoiler)[The ending of this novel will probably upset a lot of readers. Our villain, Lucy, gets away with all her crimes. Our protagonist, Alice, has been driven mad (literally) by Lucy, and Lucy manages to get away with two murders and with grossly deceiving Alice's aunt into thinking that Alice is a murderous madwoman. And the arsenic icing on this poisonous cake: Lucy steals all of the money that poor Alice inherited from her dead parents. For me, Shakespeare's Iago is the most despicable villain in all of literary history, but in Lucy, Iago has some serious competition. I have to commend Christine Mangan for her boldness in not giving the readers a pat ending where justice is finally served. Oh, no: there is no justice here, and the injustice stings terribly. And for this brutal realism that allows the narrative to unwind to its most plausible and logical end, I heartily applaud the author. (hide spoiler)]...more

title: Nineteen Eighty-Four
author: Orwell, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: When I first read Nineteen Eighty-Four as a teenager, I failed to appreciate how utterly terrifying this novel is. Obviously, it's much lauded as a woWhen I first read Nineteen Eighty-Four as a teenager, I failed to appreciate how utterly terrifying this novel is. Obviously, it's much lauded as a work of political commentary, but Nineteen Eighty-Four is also a horrifying post-apocalyptic novel, with the world of Winston Smith being far more disturbing than any of the dystopian worlds envisioned by contemporary writers.Nineteen Eighty-Four is a suffocating, psychologically draining, emotionally enervating, and physically exhausting novel. The grim, gray grunginess and cold clamminess of the London of Nineteen Eighty-Four made me feel dirty and uncomfortable as I was reading. The inescapable threat to body and mind posed by the Party induced a constant state of unease and paranoia in me as I read. Although I loved this novel, it made me feel so wretched as I was reading it that finishing it was a real relief. Nineteen Eighty-Four shows Orwell to be a master manipulator of the human psyche.The dangers that Orwell highlights in Nineteen Eighty-Four are not restricted to totalitarian states. One can see Orwellian dangers in many groups and ideologies. Of course, many political organizations tend to promote the same type of zeal and unquestioning loyalty that the Party does in Nineteen Eighty-Four, but this fanaticism is also to be found in many religious sects, in some social groups, and even among loosely organized socio-political movements that seek a strict, pure orthodoxy (as seen among, for example, the culture warriors on both the political left and right). The critique that Orwell offers is thus still relevant today although the dangers of an authoritarian state like Oceania arising seem far less likely.In addition to being a great novel of ideas, Nineteen Eighty-Four is exceptionally well written. Orwell's prose is perfectly suited to his subject matter. The language has a gritty realism that punches the reader in the face, that pummels the reader with its literary physicality. In reading this novel, the language imprisons the reader in Oceania. Orwell puts us so completely into the life and mind of Winston that we readers become Winston. Nineteen Eighty-Four feels, in many ways, like a non-fiction memoir; it feels as if it were written by someone who had escaped the oppression of Oceania.I cannot praise this novel highly enough. I love Nineteen Eighty-Four for its ideas, the power of its language, and the story of Winston himself. One of the most tragic, horrifying elements of the story is Winston's ultimate fate: in the end, he comes to truly love Big Brother. The Party apparatus has done something far worse to Winston than to physically torture him or to murder him: it has kept him alive while destroying his soul. And that is utterly terrifying....more

title: A Canticle for Leibowitz        (St. Leibowitz, #1)
author: Miller Jr., Walter M.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This three-part story is more like three separate but interrelated novellas than a fully integrated story with a single, overarching plot. The story oThis three-part story is more like three separate but interrelated novellas than a fully integrated story with a single, overarching plot. The story opens about six centuries after the twentieth century as earth is still struggling in the aftermath of a nuclear holocaust that occurred in the twentieth century. The opening section and the subsequent two sections, which are each separated from the other by several hundred years, all focus on an abbey that houses a single monastic order. The main theme that unites all three sections is the danger that nuclear weapons pose to humanity's biological and cultural survival.The opening section was interesting and fairly well done, the second less so, and the third even less so. This story has a fascinating premise but shows a lack of imagination in exploring and developing this premise. Each section focuses primarily on one or two monks and the abbot of that section's time period. There are a lot of petty, internal squabbles as well as conflicts with the world outside the abbey, but the author does very little with the distant future aspect of this story and instead basically tells two stories of medieval monks (the first two sections) and one story of monks living in a world fairly similar to our own but with slightly more advanced technology (the third section), though even in the third section, the advanced technology plays only a tertiary role.If the characterization of the monks and abbots had been better and if the general theme were more nuanced (it's fairly basic and not one really in need of emphasis to most thinking people: beware of nuclear weapons) and if the author had delved more into the science fiction possibilities inherent in his premise, this would have been a much better story. However, what we get in A Canticle for Leibowitz are three fairly hum-drum novellas; they are certainly not bad or poorly written, but they are largely forgettable and unimaginative. ...more

title: The Great Stain: Witnessing American Slavery
author: Rae, Noel
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Great Stain is a meticulously researched account of the history of slavery in North America and the Caribbean Sea, with the main focus of the bookThe Great Stain is a meticulously researched account of the history of slavery in North America and the Caribbean Sea, with the main focus of the book being on slavery in the United States. A large portion of the book is excerpts from letters, diaries, newspaper accounts, speeches, and interviews with the primary parties involved: slave traders, captains and crew of slave ships, slave owners, abolitionists, and, most important and revealing, slaves themselves. The author, Noel Rae, places these documents in their historical context and provides further explication as necessary, but, by and large, he tells the story of slavery in North America through the words of the historical actors themselves.I found this book utterly engrossing. It was fascinating to learn about the experience of crossing the Atlantic on a slave ship from the very mouths of the slaves and from the captains of those vessels. Although I had some idea about the horrors of slavery, this horror was made concrete by reading about life on plantations as told by both slaves and slave owners. The chapter on the Civil War was very disturbing as it showed how badly the black troops were treated even by their Northern comrades and officers. This book is a vast compendium of information on every aspect of slavery.The Great Stain is a marvelous work of historical research. Anyone interested in understanding slavery on a very personal level, from its beginnings in the Caribbean and later the North American continent to its final ending in the Civil War, will not find a better book than this....more

title: Gravity’s Rainbow
author: Pynchon, Thomas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Gravity's Rainbow is a long, difficult read. There are sudden shifts in narrative perspective with no warning. There is a huge cast of characters, andGravity's Rainbow is a long, difficult read. There are sudden shifts in narrative perspective with no warning. There is a huge cast of characters, and many of the minor characters are difficult to track through the novel's 776 pages. Pynchon often departs from the main narrative to ramble through extended tangents that add little of value to the overall plot--though they are often entertaining and demonstrate Pynchon's breadth of knowledge. Reality, fantasy, and memory often blend together into an indecipherable mass such that we readers are not completely sure what is actually happening.For the most part, I did not enjoy this novel; however, there are numerous episodes that are really very funny. Pynchon has a great sense of humor, and it is a humor that some would say is warped--it is often of a scatological and sexual nature--and seasoned liberally with paranoia and absurdity. Were it not for these recurrent--but still all too infrequent--humorous interludes, I would have hated this novel and rated it one star instead of two.Gravity's Rainbow is so long, so complicated, and so convoluted that, although it clearly displays Pynchon's literary genius, it becomes a chore to read. I have read other notoriously long and difficult novels (Herman Melville's Moby Dick, Leo Tolstoy's War and Peace, Fyodor Dostoevsky's The Brothers Karamazov, James Joyces's Ulysses, Gabriel Garcia Marquez's One Hundred Years of Solitude, David Foster Wallace's Infinite Jest, and Roberto Bolaño's 2666, to name a few), and I would say that Gravity's Rainbow ties with Ulysses as the most difficult, but Pynchon's novel is, in my estimation, a more interesting read than Joyce's.Upon finishing this novel, my general feeling was one of relief. I had long wanted to read it and finally made it my new year's resolution for 2018 to read it. I'm glad that I did read it. I can now understand why it is acclaimed as one of the greatest American novels of the 20th century, but I did not, overall, like it, and I would not recommend it to anyone....more

title: Atheism: The Case Against God
author: Smith, George H.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a good introduction to atheism for the layperson. When compared to the arguments against theism presented by the New Atheists (Dawkins, HarrisThis is a good introduction to atheism for the layperson. When compared to the arguments against theism presented by the New Atheists (Dawkins, Harris, Hitchens, etc.), I would say that this book is actually, despite being written for the layperson, more philosophically rigorous.The author does a very good job arguing that the concept of God is, ultimately, incoherent: the definition of God (as given by theists) either is self-contradictory in various ways or makes appeals to the unknown that render the definition meaningless. He also presents a strong epistemological attack against the possibility of acquiring knowledge by faith, and he gives relatively brief but pointed critiques of the cosmological and teleological arguments.The general tone is somewhat polemical, which may be distasteful to some readers, and some of his attacks on contemporary liberal Christianity are too simplistic. For example, he basically dismisses Tillich and other Christian pantheists as atheists in all but name, which is not fair to their positions.Overall, this is a good read that would be especially valuable to someone unfamiliar with the basic arguments for atheism and against God....more

title: Girls Burn Brighter
author: Rao, Shobha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Girls Burn Brighter is quietly yet profoundly tragic. It is the story of two young Indian women from a small village. As we follow their lives, their Girls Burn Brighter is quietly yet profoundly tragic. It is the story of two young Indian women from a small village. As we follow their lives, their friendship, and their journeys (both geographically as well as personally and psychologically), we are exposed to the degradation and horror of misogyny, poverty, and present-day slavery. But there is a redemptive arc: the faith that these young women have in each other and their friendship.To say that this novel is bleak and pessimistic is accurate, but the point of this novel is not to tell a depressing story; rather, this novel is giving us a glimpse of a reality of which most of us (at least those of us in the West) are grossly ignorant, and this reality is, in many respects, very dark. The two protagonists, Poornima and Savitha, are perfectly realized, and as young women living in a culture where, for many, women have value only as wives and mothers, they experience crushing poverty, sexual harassment and assault, and psychological and physical abuse. Despite living under such conditions, they do not lose hope; their friendship sustains them.This novel left me in tears several times. It was a hard read: reading about sexual and physical violence and abject poverty is never easy, and often we readers fear that Poornima and Savitha will either go on to live lives of great suffering or die young. Nevertheless, because the book was so very well written, because the characters were so exceptionally well drawn, and because the book is so educational (we learn a lot about rural life and culture in contemporary India and about the modern plague of slavery, which still exists in India and around the world, even in the United States), I can without any reservations recommend Girls Burn Brighter....more

title: Flowers in the Attic        (Dollanganger, #1)
author: Andrews, V.C.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: If I were to channel Cathy, the adolescent narrator of Flowers in the Attic, in order to sum up my opinion of this novel in her voice, I would say, "OIf I were to channel Cathy, the adolescent narrator of Flowers in the Attic, in order to sum up my opinion of this novel in her voice, I would say, "Oh, golly day, but Flowers in the Attic is just so darned bad!" Some of my actual exclamations, uttered as I sat on my couch marveling at how stupendously atrocious this novel is, were:"Oh, come on!""You have got to be kidding me!""This is so fucking ridiculous!"It's truly remarkable that I did not hurl this insipid book across the room.No novel is more worthy of being assessed as the most unholy incarnation of melodrama than is Flowers in the Attic: this is one long (much too long!) soap opera, full of disgusting, unapologetically incestuous titillation, a completely unbelievable premise (even when suspending one's disbelief for the sake of fiction), plot twists that violently violate all conventions of the narrative logic (although, in defense of this novel, logic is rarely given much consideration), and characters so paper-thin and poorly developed as to make the likes of Bugs Bunny, Elmer Fudd, and Woody Woodpecker appear as Lear, Macbeth, and Hamlet in comparison.The characters' motivations, decisions, and actions make little to no sense. The entire plot may well be a huge practical joke on the foolish readers (like myself) who continue reading to the inane and wholly disappointing end. But, of course, if anything in this novel had made sense, then this ludicrous, fourth-rate soap opera posing as a novel would not have had any story to tell at all.Were I so inclined, I could spin out 10 or 12 or 50 paragraphs enumerating the flaws, the non sequiturs, and the bewildering stupidity of this novel. But I've wasted enough time already in simply reading it and writing this much, so I shall say only that if you are considering reading this drivel, spare yourself and read something with more literary merit--like your grocery list or the hieroglyphic scratchings in your cats' litter box....more

review: This novel is a testament to the power of fiction. While most of us can intellectually grasp some of the reasons for the divisions between Israeli JewThis novel is a testament to the power of fiction. While most of us can intellectually grasp some of the reasons for the divisions between Israeli Jews and Palestinians, we are unable to fathom the emotional depths and the deeply ingrained, historically-based passions involved. This novel, more than anything else I've read or seen, has made the Israeli-Palestinian conflict vividly real to me. And the author achieved this effect with grace, nuance, brilliant character development, and a refusal to try to simplify the complexities of the situation. This is a novel about three individuals on the verge of adulthood--two Palestinians and an Israeli Jew--who form a friendship. They become very close, growing to love each other--and even falling in love. In giving us an intimate portrait of this friendship, this novel also helps us understand the social and political realities in contemporary Israel and Palestine.It is one of the best books of 2018....more

author: Lee, Sang-Hee
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For anyone unfamiliar with human evolution, this book is a good introduction. Because each chapter was originally a self-contained article in a KoreanFor anyone unfamiliar with human evolution, this book is a good introduction. title: The Hazel Wood        (The Hazel Wood, #1)
author: Albert, Melissa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What if the fairy tale world infringed upon our world?That is the premise of this novel, but the fairy tales in The Hazel Wood are not the cheery, sanWhat if the fairy tale world infringed upon our world?That is the premise of this novel, but the fairy tales in The Hazel Wood are not the cheery, sanitized fairy tales of Disney but the older, darker fairy tales where the endings are not always happy, the princesses and princes not always pure of heart, and the fairies not always benevolent and noble. The fairy tales in this novel are the stuff of nightmares. And those nightmares are encroaching into our world.The Hazel Wood is shelved in the YA section of my library, but I would argue that this is more of a novel for adults in terms of the content, the exceptional quality of the prose, and the meta-narrative themes it addresses. I think a 14- or 15-year-old would probably be able to enjoy this novel but would likely not be able to fully appreciate it. This novel, in terms of its maturity and brooding psychological realism, reminded me in many ways of Lev Grossman's The Magicians trilogy. Like the Grossman novels, The Hazel Wood is a much darker fantasy story than the Narnia or Harry Potter novels.I love the premise of this novel, and the writing and characterization are great. Melissa Albert has an extraordinary talent for sensory description: I could see, feel, and smell the world that she created and felt, many times, like I was inside the skin of her characters. While I liked the ending, it was not quite as good as the earlier portions of the novel, so I am rating this four stars instead of five, but I still found this to be a very enjoyable novel overall, and I was delighted to learn that this is the first novel in a series. I will definitely be reading the next novel in this continuing saga of Alice Proserpine and the Hinterland (the fairy tale world)....more

title: A River in Darkness:  One Man's Escape from North Korea
author: Ishikawa, Masaji
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a fascinating first-hand account of life in North Korea. The author, Masaji Ishikawa, details the hardships and tragedies that he and his famiThis is a fascinating first-hand account of life in North Korea. The author, Masaji Ishikawa, details the hardships and tragedies that he and his family endured for over 30 years under the brutal North Korean dictatorship. In reading the story, I felt like Ishikawa himself were speaking directly to me. The book has a rough, visceral feel to it; it's not refined and not terribly well written, but it is unflinchingly honest. This book allows you to walk in Ishikawa's shoes and experience his pain, disappointment, despair, and harsh physical suffering. Sadly, it doesn't have a happy ending: although Ishikawa himself escapes North Korea, his family does not, and as the book closes, he is beset with loneliness and depression because his family members (at least those who have not yet succumbed to death) are still trapped in North Korea.A River in Darkness paints a graphic picture of just how horrific life North Korea is, and it left me deeply saddened for Ishikawa, his family, and his fellow citizens....more

title: The Hound of the Baskervilles        (Sherlock Holmes, #5)
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Hound of the Baskervilles has the feeling of a story written for the express purpose of trying to sell the story. It simply does not feel genuine.The Hound of the Baskervilles has the feeling of a story written for the express purpose of trying to sell the story. It simply does not feel genuine. It reads like a tabloid story: a demon dog kills an eldery man and remains on the prowl! Doyle throws in a lurid legend of kidnapping, an escaped convict, a woman abused by her husband, strange goings-on in the night in a huge country estate among the servants, and frequent references to characters having their guns and being ready to use them. Having never previously read any of Doyle's novels, I was was surprised by this level of prurience. The novel is sloppy. The prose is unpolished and unrefined, and there is an obvious error in the narrative timeline: in Chapter 9, Watson writes a letter, dated October 15, to Holmes describing the previous night's adventures (in which he and Sir Henry had chased Selden, the escaped convict, on the moor), and he refers to this event as occurring "last night" which would have been the night of October 14. Then, in Chapter 10, we are given a diary entry from Watson dated October 16; before the diary entry, Watson notes that this entry describes the morning after he and Sir Henry had chased Selden; since the diary date is October 16, that would mean the chase occurred the night of October 15, not October 14, as the letter to Holmes indicates. The general mystery itself is not all that mysterious. Early on, the story references the three Baskerville brothers and notes that one had gone to South America, and I immediately thought it likely that this third brother might somehow be involved in the death of Sir Charles, and (view spoiler)[I was right, to a degree: it was the son of the brother who had gone to South America (hide spoiler)]. I was further disappointed that this story does not portray Holmes as making any particularly brilliant or ingenious deductions. One of the main clues that Holmes uses to crack the mystery is seeing a portrait in Baskerville Hall of one of the Baskerville ancestors and seeing a family resemblance to the murderer. This was just not a very intriguing mystery.One final major problem with this story is that we are never told the murderer's ultimate fate. The penultimate chapter ends with Holmes, Watson, and the police detective going to the hideout where the murderer had kept the hound, but the murderer is not there, and they do not immediately give chase and find him. As this chapter ends, the murderer is at large. Then, in the final chapter, we have Holmes explaining to Watson in detail how he solved the case, but he never mentions anything about the murderer either escaping or being apprehended. Maybe it's just me, but this is a pretty important plot detail. I do not mean to imply that The Hound of the Baskervilles is completely bad, though. It was still an entertaining read, and I was interested in the mystery behind the hound: exactly how big was it; why was it so bloodthirsty; why was it thought to be some sort of hell hound? However, the revelation was less than satisfying: it was the size of a small lioness, which is not really all that big; it was half-staved by the murderer, so it was obviously in a state to kill a human for food; and the murderer had coated its muzzle and hackles with phosphorous to give it an eerie glow.One other positive aspect of this novel is that it is very short and is an easy read with a lot of dialogue and action. But is it a classic novel? I don't think so....more

title: Gnomon
author: Harkaway, Nick*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Nick Harkaway is a literary genius, and we wander through his remarkably twisted (in both senses) mind as he takes us down a labyrinthine rabbit hole Nick Harkaway is a literary genius, and we wander through his remarkably twisted (in both senses) mind as he takes us down a labyrinthine rabbit hole to rival any and all rabbit holes. Gnomon is one of the most ambitious and imaginative books I have ever read. It is its own unique self while hearkening to (and perhaps paying homage to) Jorge Luis Borges's short stories, Mark Z. Danielewski's House of Leaves, Steven Hall's The Raw Shark Texts, and Thomas Pynchon's Gravity's Rainbow.I could no more summarize Gnomon than I could the Bible. This is a dense novel--both literally (in terms of its physical size and weight) and intellectually. It is not an easy read, and if you find yourself lost in the journey that it takes you on, don't be surprised, for what else would you expect from diving into the whirlwind?As I was starting to write this paragraph, I intended to give my justification for rating this novel four stars instead of five. I was going to say that this was a novel that I very much appreciated but did not thoroughly enjoy, and then I immediately went and changed my rating from four to five stars because, although it was a difficult read and not always enjoyable, to rate it only four stars would be an injustice. Yes, it is a long read and is often arduous. You can't just breeze through it like some airport thriller or the sci-fi flavor of the month. This novel is not for the faint of heart. Gnomon is brilliant. It left me breathless. I have a feeling that Gnomon, like Danielewski's House of Leaves, will be one that, years from now, will continue to stand out in my memory for the sheer audacity of the author's vision and the intricate precision of its execution.I often finish a novel and remark to myself how much I enjoyed it. It's not difficult to write interesting and enjoyable novels. But rarely do I finish a novel and say to myself, "That was impressive." Gnomon is impressive....more

review: I Was Told to Come Alone is a spy thriller.And a biography.And a dark comedy.And a tragedy.And a socio-cultural analysis of why and how the West and sI Was Told to Come Alone is a spy thriller.And a biography.And a dark comedy.And a tragedy.And a socio-cultural analysis of why and how the West and some Muslims in the West, North Africa, and the Middle East so often and so badly misunderstand one another.Of course, it is also the story of exactly what it is like to be a journalist covering the stories of war, terrorism, refugees, and revolution in the Middle East, North Africa, and the West over the last two decades.And it is surprisingly entertaining while also being extremely educational and enlightening.If you are interested in a detailed, nuanced account of the roots of the terrorism that has plagued the West over the past 20 years, I Was Told to Come Alone is a must-read....more

title: The Immortalists
author: Benjamin, Chloe*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was crying by the time I finished this novel--both tears of joy and of sadness. And the novel earned these tears through careful, exquisite characteI was crying by the time I finished this novel--both tears of joy and of sadness. And the novel earned these tears through careful, exquisite character building and meticulous storytelling. This is not a sappy, sentimental novel. It is a thoughtful, considered, and utterly engrossing portrayal of a family.The relationships among four siblings (two sisters and two brothers) are at the heart of this novel, and Chloe Benjamin shows the complexity--from the petty rivalries and jealousies on one end of the spectrum to the intense protectiveness and love on the other--of the ties that bind sisters and brothers together from, of course, earliest childhood all the way to the end of life.As I was reading this novel, I was constantly thinking about the title: who are the immortalists, and what makes them immortal? (Minor spoiler for those who think this novel falls into the fantasy genre: no one in this novel is literally immortal.) With a question like this, there can be no concrete, definitive answer, but I'll make a stab at it. To some degree, I think all of us like the idea of immortality, but being humans, we know that literal immortality is not in the cards. So who or what is immortal? This may sound cheesy and trite, but it really is not: I think that this novel teaches us that only love is immortal. The love that binds families and friends together transcends human mortality, and so those of us who partake in this love achieve at least a measure of immortality. When we cut ourselves off from love, we die although we may still live. But when we love, we become immortal even though we die.I should also say something about the expectations that many readers might have about this novel and about the pacing. Much of the press surrounding this novel and even the dust jacket reference the opening scene in which the four siblings go to a fortune teller who tells each one the exact date of her/his death. This is an important element of the story, but it's not what this story is about. This is not a work of fantasy or even of magical realism. This is a work of literary fiction--and very good literary fiction at that.With regards to the pacing, the novel does begin rather slowly. After 30 or 40 pages, I questioned whether I should keep going. I wasn't, at that point in time, all that interested in either the story or the characters. But I am so glad I continued reading. You can't create well developed characters quickly and easily. It takes time, and so Chloe Benjamin slowly and patiently brings her characters to life. And the more you get to know these four siblings, the more you come to love them and to care about their individual and interconnected stories. I loved this book. I found it profoundly moving. Exceptional fiction can teach us deeper, more meaningful, more powerful truths than non-fiction, and The Immortalists is such a novel. This is a novel that will make you weep. It will remind you of what matters most in life....more

title: The Woman in the Window
author: Finn, A.J.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Take all of the psychological thrillers published in the last 15 to 20 years. Feed all of their tired tropes and hackneyed twists and trembling, troubTake all of the psychological thrillers published in the last 15 to 20 years. Feed all of their tired tropes and hackneyed twists and trembling, troubled, yet ultimately triumphant protagonists (oh, how, for the sake of alliteration, I wish the word were trotagonists) into a literary AI, and it will spit out something resembling The Woman in the Window.It's not that The Woman in the Window is a bad novel. It's competently written. It does maintain your interest--at least for the first half and then again near the end. It has moments where you are genuinely flummoxed (in a good way) and moments where you are mildly interested in what might happen next. But there is nothing new here. If psychological thrillers are a dime a dozen (and they are), you'll need to read this one plus 11 more to get your full 10 cents worth.You've read this novel before. Maybe not with these exact characters or these specific plot details, but the broad outlines are all there. The lonely woman with a haunted past. Who drinks too much. Who has dark secrets. Who stumbles upon a crime. Who is believed by no one. Who is even thought to be crazy. But, in the end, well, if you are expecting something original, I'm sorry. This is a novel which, again, you've already read, so you won't be surprised.In four or five months, you'll barely remember any details of this novel. Certainly not the protagonist's name. Nor that of her nemesis. Nor the motives. These types of novels all blur into a morass of forgettable blandness. But perhaps I'm being too harsh. It's not terrible. Apart from being terribly unoriginal. It's entertaining enough, but so is a re-run of "Law and Order" or "Frasier."...more

review: A migrant washes up on the shores of a small Greek island where the idle rich spend their summers. An unlikely crime is committed, a cover-up follows,A migrant washes up on the shores of a small Greek island where the idle rich spend their summers. An unlikely crime is committed, a cover-up follows, and then a sharp, dogged investigator shows up and quickly discovers clues that send him down the right trail. With these elements, Lawrence Osborne creates a nearly perfect thriller. My expectations, drawing on the standard fare of mystery and thriller novels, were--to my delight--foiled numerous times as the novel took unexpected but plausible turns. This novel begins a bit slowly but gains steam quickly and grows more fascinating as the plot develops until it reaches the nearly perfect resolution. The characterization and pacing are very well done, and the prose is first-rate. Beautiful Animals is a beautiful novel....more

title: The Power
author: Alderman, Naomi*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: With women possessing an inherent capacity, lacking in men, to produce and manipulate electricity (similar to that of electric eels), women are naturaWith women possessing an inherent capacity, lacking in men, to produce and manipulate electricity (similar to that of electric eels), women are naturally more powerful than men.What would this world be like? Would a world dominated by women be less violent and less oppressive than the patriarchal world in which we now live? Would it be a better world? Would women, in how they rule, show themselves to be morally superior to men? These are the questions asked and answered in The Power.The idea of this novel is inherently fascinating, and mythical tales and legends of the Amazons aside, I can't recall encountering this idea so completely and fully realized elsewhere in literature. Overall, I enjoyed this novel, though the plot is somewhat slow and disjointed for the first third to half of the novel, but by the last half, the narrative momentum moves swiftly and keeps the reader fully engaged. With five primary characters (Allie, Roxy, Margot, Jocelyn, and Tunde), the characterization is underdeveloped. Only Roxy is a fully realized, relatable character. Tunde is also fairly well drawn, but the remaining three characters lack solidity, lack depth. And we do not get to know Allie, Margot, and Jocelyn well enough, nor do we care about them, though this is not the case with Roxy and Tunde. But this is a novel more about the plot than the characters, and with the plot being so good, the problems with the characterization are not so bad.What I most like about this novel is the question that it asks about matriarchy. Many of us (myself included) presume that a matriarchy would be better than a patriarchy. I don't want to spoil anything, so I won't say how this novel addresses this issue, but I will say that the author does a great job of examining this question and does so in a unique and interesting fashion. This novel is a very enjoyable extended thought experiment....more

title: The Three-Body Problem        (Remembrance of Earth’s Past, #1)
author: Liu, Cixin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The science of The Three-Body Problem is challenging but still intelligible for the layperson.The science fiction is beautifully imagined yet plausiblThe science of The Three-Body Problem is challenging but still intelligible for the layperson.The science fiction is beautifully imagined yet plausible, though far from feasible--at least for contemporary humans. The premise, (view spoiler)[an alien race, the Trisolarans, is able to manipulate subatomic particles in higher dimensions: they take a single proton, which is unimaginably vast in higher dimensions, and unfold it into a large sheet in 2-dimensional space; they engrave this unfolded proton with circuits, like a computer chip, such that the single proton is transformed into a computer with computing powers far beyond anything of which humanity's computers are capable (hide spoiler)], grabs the far borders of speculation and pulls them down into the realm of seeming possibility, creating a nearly perfect hard science fiction plot.Like the best science fiction, The Three-Body Problem engages the perennial questions--though perhaps not in as much detail as I would have liked--of moral and existential philosophy and of religion.For the most part, the characters (even the main characters, Wang Miao and Ye Wenjie) are underdeveloped, with the exception of the stand-out character, the brusque yet ever engaging Da Shi (Shi Qiang), but that's not really an issue: The Three-Body Problem has bigger fish to fry. All the men and women are merely players on the world's stage. The bigger drama is that of the world itself and its collision with a strange, distant alien world--a world that is even closer than we might otherwise have thought.For all the science and speculation, this novel still has a lot of heart. It's endlessly fascinating--spiced with danger, mystery, intrigue, and betrayal--and it will keep you turning the pages wanting more and more. The Three-Body Problem will make you think. It will educate you in both physics (for many of us) but especially in matters of Chinese culture and history (at least for those of us who aren't Chinese). It will make you ask questions you might never have even thought to ask. It will challenge you. It will entertain you. And that all makes for a great science fiction novel....more

title: White Tears
author: Kunzru, Hari*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Why do they sing the blues? It's a simple question. The answer is so much less than simple.And Hari Kunzru, in White Tears, gives you the answer. He dWhy do they sing the blues? It's a simple question. The answer is so much less than simple.And Hari Kunzru, in White Tears, gives you the answer. He doesn't force it on you. He doesn't beat you over the head, though by the end, you'll be black and blue. Hari Kunzru takes you by the hand, gently leading you to the path. At first, you think you're reading a story about friendship and making music. You go on, and suddenly you think maybe you're in some sort of ghost story, maybe a tale of the occult or of demon possession, or could it be a psychotic episode, or is it some strange looping time travel twisting the narrative into knots?It's a puzzle. It's not hard to put together, but actually putting it together is hard, is unpleasant, is horrifying, even. You will go places you don't want to go. See things you don't want to see. See a history you'd love to forget. And you will find the answer. Mark it down. You will understand the blues.But this isn't a story about the blues. This is a story about American history. About America trying to forget the past. And worse: trying not to see the present. But it's also a story of myopia. Of frenetic visions and sweating, chaotic fear. A story of karma. A story of that darkness. You know that darkness. We all do. We've all seen and unseen that darkness.You can't summarize this novel and do it any justice. You must read it. It will possess you. Or maybe you will possess it. Or something of both. You'll be in this reality that leaves you questioning reality but never leaves you. And you'll get answers. You might not like them. Hell, if you do like them, there's something wrong with you. Who ever said the truth had to be nice and pretty?White Tears is among the best novels I've read this decade. Kunzru's prose . . . I am unable to put into words just how good it is. This man can write. Not just write: he can create. This novel is a world that you live in, that lives in you. Try to read this entire novel without exclaiming in awe at its brilliance. Multiple times. This is the word made flesh. This is holy writ. Words are so insufficient. The best I can do to express my awe of this book is just to say, "God damn!" ...more

title: The Girl in the Tower        (The Winternight Trilogy, #2)
author: Arden, Katherine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Girl in the Tower, the second book in the Winternight Trilogy, is every bit as good as, maybe even a little better than, the first book. KatherineThe Girl in the Tower, the second book in the Winternight Trilogy, is every bit as good as, maybe even a little better than, the first book. Katherine Arden is proving herself to be among the best contemporary fantasy writers.The harsh cold of a Russian winter in early medieval times serves as the backdrop for a dark fairy tale that features palace intrigue, marauding thieves laying waste the countryside, an evil priest, a warrior monk, a young woman perilously posing as a young man, a powerful sorcerer, ghosts, demons, talking horses, and magical charms and weapons. And it works. My god, it works!This book completely swept me away to medieval Moscow and the near-arctic Russian steppes. I could feel the brutal cold, smell the sweat of the horses, see the vast whiteness of the ubiquitous snow, and hear the clamor of bustling Moscow. The characters came fully to life, and I loved and feared for our protagonist, Vasya, angered by the injustices she suffered. I loved that Arden kept us in the dark for much of the novel about who the real villain was behind the scenes, pulling the strings and trying to manipulate Vasya.The Girl in the Tower is extremely well-plotted with a near perfect ending. Reading this book was an absolute pleasure, and I can hardly wait to read the final installment in this trilogy....more
